Take two founders of a dotcom company. Overnight one becomes a celebrity while the other languishes in the background, despite the fact that he is the senior of the two. She becomes something of an icon to the City while he is still able to shop in Tesco without being recognised.

'It's interesting to reflect on the attention given to Lastminute.com, says Professor John Quelch, dean of London Business School (LBS). 'Martha Lane Fox got much more press coverage than Brent Hoberman, which suggests there was something more unique about her in the minds of the media than him. It's a reflection of the problem facing women in business.'

The depressing fact is that, despite all the talk of closing gender gaps over the last few years, men still wear the trousers in the business world. The few women like Lane Fox who have made it to the top of the tree are seen as freaks, which serves only to reinforce stereotypes and, ultimately, exacerbate the corporate gender divide.

LBS is so concerned at the lack of senior female executives that later this week it will hold a high-profile conference - 'Breaking the Mould' - in an attempt to attract more women to the university and into the business world at large. Only 22 per cent of the school's students are women, reflecting the fact that they form less than a quarter of those who apply. It is a statistic common to business schools nationwide.

Quelch says: 'If you take a profession like medicine or the law, you find women have broken through. About 50 per cent of the people in these two are women. Even in engineering women are making headway. But in business...'

Indeed. The facts are overly familiar. Only one woman - Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of Pearson - heads a FTSE 100 company. Less than 5 per cent of non-executive positions in those companies are held by women. Last week a comprehensive report into executive pay by the research company Incomes Data Services showed that in this financial year a female FTSE 350 director could expect to receive total earnings - including bonuses and share options - of £261,000. Her male counterpart, however, would be in line for a package just shy of £400,000.

Even in the US, seen as home to a more enlightened business culture than the old boy network represented in the Square Mile, there seem few grounds for optimism. An exhaustive study by the National Bureau of Economic Research, which analysed US salary data between 1992 and 1997, showed that women executives earned one-third less than men over the same period: $900,000 compared with $1.3 million - although the differentials were heavily skewed by disparities in age and experience. Even so, it is still a fact that less than 5 per cent of women reach the most senior executive positions in American companies.

But the UK seems to be one of the worst offenders when it comes to top jobs for the boys. Success stories are few and far between. Scardino does, after all, hail from the US. The UK's second highest-profile businesswoman, Barbara Cassani, chief executive of BA's low-cost airline Go, is also from over the pond. A recent edition of Fortune magazine was big on female high-flyers in the US - as you would expect - but it also waxed lyrical about French and Japanese businesswomen. The UK was, with the exception of Scardino, sadly lacking.

The entrenched patriarchal structure of the business world might make for a cosy club, but it doesn't make for strong corporate performances, according to Quelch. This is because the new, knowledge-based economy places much greater emphasis on the need to create enduring working relationships between companies. More and more companies are sharing information, brands and personnel, calling for new management skills.

'The types of challenges facing businesses today are often about managing joint ventures or strategic partnerships. It's not about being a bull in a china shop like the old days. The competitiveness of the UK economy depends on it leveraging the talents of its people and obviously there are demands for people with these sorts of management skills,' Quelch says.

Elizabeth Coffey, author of The Changing Culture of Leadership: Women Leaders' Voices, agrees with Quelch's analysis. She studied 50 of the top businesswomen in the UK and compared their styles of leadership with their male counterparts.

'Women are much more into developing learning cultures. They'll create teams rather than divisions and hierarchies,' says Coffey.

It might sound New Age mumbo jumbo to the pinstriped brigade but Coffey argues that companies will have to start taking such cultures far more seriously in the future. 'Companies will start to pay more attention to this when they ask "who are our customers?" Customers are increasingly female.'

Indeed they are, and it's not just in the obvious conventional retail departments that women are making the purchasing decisions. Four-fifths of all car-buying decisions are made or influenced by women. A survey in the US found that nearly 60 per cent of all car tyre purchases were made by women.

'Companies need to understand how their customers think. That's a primary driver for setting up these learning cultures, so they know how to react,' Coffey says.

The trend to outsourcing is also having an effect. Anna Lloyd, of the Committee of 200, a US society for leading businesswomen, says: 'The market place is demanding a different perspective in relationships. A lot of tasks are now outsourced and consultants are doing everything on the payroll. Managers have to interact differently. The old ways of managing things are changing.'

But, even if this argument holds water, few companies so far give it credence. 'There is still a lot of prejudice against women around. Companies are more aware that they need women in senior posts and they may appoint some more, but does that mean they're just token gestures?' asks Bronwyn Curtis, managing director of Bloomberg TV and Radio in Europe.

Curtis, who was a few years ago the former chief economist at Japanese bank Nomura - still the only woman to have held such a position at a high-profile finance house - is cynical about the future. 'It [the gender gap] is better than when I started in the City in 1987, but I don't think you'll see drastic changes in the next five years. Maybe in the next 10 to 15, but it will take a new generation of men to change it.'

All of the women interviewed by The Observer for this article stressed that men's support will be crucial if women are to break through the glass ceilings of tomorrow. Even at the domestic level this seems vital. Coffey cited research which showed that nearly three-quarters of leading businesswomen claim to have supportive husbands who are sympathetic to their job commitments.

One day we may be saying 'Behind every great woman...' but don't hold your breath.

The gender gap

Women may be finding it difficult to break into the upper echelons of the UK's largest companies but at least there are grounds for optimism in the wider business world. Today, women hold three times as many managerial roles as they did a decade ago, according to a recent report by the Institute of Management.

The report also found that women are closing the gender pay gap. Typically, male managers are paid 8 per cent more than their female counterparts, compared with 38 per cent more a decade ago. Over the past year women managers' pay rose by 6.4 per cent compared with the 5.4 per cent rise received by their male counterparts.

In addition, more women are now making it into the boardroom. Nearly 10 per cent of companies now boast a woman on their board compared with just under 2 per cent 10 years ago.

There is also evidence that women are becoming more entrepreneurial. More than a third of all business start-ups are formed by women. In the US the figure is even more dramatic. Female-owned businesses are the fastest area of business growth in the US, according to the Centre for Policy Alternatives. These businesses now employ one in four of the working population.

We all saw the pictures. The deep eye sockets. The streamline features. The gleaming cranium, radiating energy in the glare of his own NBC television lights. We heard the shoot-from-the-hip lingo as he explained how he just snapped together that $45 billion deal between his turbine to twin-tub combine General Electric and industrial controls group Honeywell, in three days.

He told us how a tip from a reporter led him to fax Honeywell's chairman nine days' ago and close a deal gazumping his rival United Technologies the following day. As a result of this masterstroke he's putting off his retirement. But, hey, he's taking the risk: his family has only company stock to live on. He's not doing it because he's an old man who can't let go. To anyone who disagrees, he says: 'I want to take them on right in the chops'.

How do you describe a man like Jack Welch? 'A dynamo,' says one expert. 'A connoisseur of talent,' says another.

'We call him The Penguin,' says one less enamoured engineering firm that has to compete with him rather than lecture about him. 'Tell me if he does not look like Batman's biggest headache. The problem is he has that effect on the competition.'

Welch unnerves people. One official at aero-engine manufacturer Rolls-Royce says: 'One of our executives once asked Jack at a conference what he though Rolls should do. 'Just stay in big engines,' he said. 'Our people spent a while puzzling out whether this was good advice, or if he was trying to get one over on us.'

He unnerves for a reason. Though he talks macho, synergies with Honeywell worth $1.5 billion were 'right in the gunsights' - he delivers.

General Electric is the first and last word in conglomerates. He has built it from the $13bn company he took over in 1981 into the world's biggest company, worth $530 billion.

It has 340,000 employees - 465,000 after the latest merger - in 100 countries, with revenues of $111.6 bn. It sells everything from light bulbs to dishwashers and ovens, to electrical switchgear, aero engines and financial services.

At 64, Welch's raw energy remains famous. One of his better known sobriquets is Neutron Jack - a phrase that gets close to the heart of the man: he destroys whatever gets in the way of what he wants to build. He is charismatic and competitive and has great charm, according to those who have met him. He has judgment - GE is as much about successful delegation as it is about Welch himself - and he is canny.

'All that nonsense about him depending on the success of the deal,' says another competitor. 'He has been getting millions in bonuses. But it's typical Welch: he knows some people will believe it, and he knows they think he does.' Welch is the eighth highest paid US executive, says Forbes magazine .

His upbringing is suspiciously close to the ideal American dream, an idea the old myth-maker does little to discourage. For example, a converted gravel pit in his native Salem, Massachusetts - requisitioned by local boys who ran it themselves because there were no state leisure facilities - was where his first fist fights and ball games were played out. Naturally, he rose to the top.

But for the record, he was born the only son of a railway conductor. His father was often away from home so he was raised by his ambitious mother.

Welch was not shy about ambition himself. He had an accomplished spell at Salem High school, where he was co-captain of golf - he is still very keen - played hockey, and held the post of treasurer.

His teachers said in his college yearbook: 'A keen wit, a wise look and an answer always ready.' Welch said in the school literary magazine: 'repressed desire - to make a million.'

He went to the University of Massachusetts for a degree in chemical engineering, followed by a Phd at the University of Illinois.

He joined GE's plastics division in 1960. Plastics was a buzzing area, with new markets being developed. His career has perhaps come full circle. With the acquisition of Honeywell, GE's $250m plastics division gains critical mass.

'Back then,' says one business analyst, 'he learnt you have to innovate ceaselessly to get margins.'

Welch sped through GE. By 1981 he was joint chief executive and chairman. Jay Conger, professor of leadership at the London Business School, says one of the keys to Welch was spotting defining new trends and remodelling the business around them. 'Control your destiny or die,' he said.

His first initiative was to force the company's operations to focus at being number one or number two in its market. If it wasn't it had to get there. If it couldn't, it would go. This not only refocused the business - hundreds of underperforming operations went - it refocused management and weeded out those who weren't up to scratch.

He called his next move 'speed, simplicity, self confidence'. Welch viewed the GE bureaucracy - an industrial civil service - with suspicion. So he smashed it, gaining that Neutron Jack tag. He thinned out divisions, fired thousands of staff, shed layers of management. Each division would be a business 'laboratory', creating ideas and deciding the best way of making money from them.

Late in the Eighties Welch latched onto globalisation, which he called 'boundarylessness'. GE needed to think globally about everything from labour markets, suppliers and customers to business practice, generating its own ideas and taking them from others.

On top of this it created businesses such as a leasing and financial services division, which made its own products such as aero-engines more easily available. This division now generates $55.75bn of revenue. He realised margins were in servicing engines, not manufacturing them, so bought independent aero engine workshops around the world.

GE has faced challenges throughout - such as the Kidder Peabody financial scandal, which saw a rogue trader lose the financial services arm millions - and some observers have criticised the increasing dominance of financial services. But to his admirers, Welch's success has depended on meeting problems, such as the internet, head on. His response to that? 'destroyyourbusiness.com', an initiative to show top managers that the Net was do or die for GE. The group claims it has already gained $5bn from online operations.

He has faced criticism for it. Last year, for example, Forbes hinted that Welch might be a dinosaur thrashing about in a new age when he refused to link the pay of young webmeisters he had brought in to the profits of their operations. The young things began to defect to dotcoms. Welch was allegedly furious - but who's laughing now?

For Jay Conger there's more to Welch than the corporate engineer. 'Jack Welch is one of the great dealmakers. People know they are facing the quickest mind in business. But there is more than that - they know they are dealing with one of the world's only business celebrities. Welch knows he's going to do a good deal for GE, and so do they.' Thus far it seems self fulfilling - the 1,700 acquisitions under Welch have created GE as a savvy and agile conglomerate.

There are sceptics, particularly over Honeywell. One UK analyst says: 'This could be the mark of an organisation looking for places for its capital. The big question isn't whether Honeywell's a great fit - it isn't perfect - but whether it indicates GE running out of steam. Was it the big man's last gambit?'

Honeywell will almost certainly be his swan song. True to form he has managed his succession - picking candidates and designing the selection process. But will he choose the right man? And has he left a structure that they can build on?

'You wait to see what comes out of the woodwork when he's gone,' says another analyst. 'There's a lesson from the UK. Remember that famously autocratic and successful British boss Lord Weinstock. Do you remember what his company was called?'

Answers on a postcard.

Vital signs

Subject: John F Welch Jr

Age: 64

Job: Chairman and chief executive, General Electric

Hobbies: Golf, baseball, competing

Sayings of chairman Jack

'We will only be number one or two or else we will sell it, fix it or close it.'

'Companies can't give job security. Only customers can.'

'Muscle is the answer. When you have 10 diverse businesses, you have 10 popgun stalls. When they are constructed into one entity that can really do the job, that gives you muscle.'

Anatomy of a giant

Jack Welch may seem like a big deal, but even his stature is dwarfed by the company he runs. General Electric is an American industrial institution. Its origins go back to the 1878 foundation of the Edison Electric company, which turned into GE in 1892. The company history reads like a chronicle of US industrial progress.

Between 1882 and 1968 it built the US's first central power station, launched its domestic appliance company, created the RCA radio corporation, entered commercial aircraft engine manufacture, opened the first licensed nuclear power plant and pioneered consumer, commercial and industrial credit and leasing.

But while the company's life blood has been building industrial businesses across many sectors of US business, its brains, particularly since Welch became a vice president in the Seventies, have been deployed as one of the country's most astute corporate operators.

Under Welch GE has become a deal-making machine - to the tune of some 1,700 acquisitions. Indeed, Welch cited his skills at bedding in deals, particularly the 1985 acquisition of the RCA media business, as the main reason for staying on.

In 1981 GE moved into semiconductors, buying Intercil. In 1983 it consolidated its position in medical scanning technology through acquisition.

A string of deals since then has built GE Capital Services into a massive consumer credit, industrial and commercial financing and leasing operation which dominates the business - some would say too much so.

Welch has also pursued other strategies by acquisition, for example backing his belief in the margins of servicing rather than building aero-engines by buying BA's operations in Wales in 1991 and Greenwich Air services and UNC in 1997.

He's also bought into mobile phones - a joint venture with Ericsson in 1991 - and snapped up operations that fit with the companies earliest origins, such as Thorn EMI's light bulb business in 1991.

He has also jettisoned extraneous operations, such as non financial broadcasting, oil and gas exploration and problematic operations such as Kidder Peabody financial business.

One disposal, made in 1970 when he had been at the company 10 years, may have caught his eye. In that year GE sold its mainframe computer business to Honeywell. Last week's deal brings the business back to GE.

But the world is split over whether Jack's done well on this one. Initial reaction from the markets was twitchy - GE's value dropped by about 4.8 per cent.

Analysts rallied, however, pointing to the strategic fit in aerospace, where GE's $10.6 billion of aero engine sales was matched by Honeywell's $10.5 billion cockpit avionics business. They also pointed to a broader customer base for GE's industrial systems brought by Honeywell's controls division.

Welch himself defended the acquisition of the chemicals business, saying it bulked GE's $250m activities up by $1bn.

He added that these are real technology businesses, with real earnings and real products - unlike the dotcoms - and pointed to real $1.5bn savings from the '90 per cent fit' of the businesses.

In a Merrill Lynch note out on Wednesday analyst Jeanne Terrile says if GE successfully integrates Honeywell it could be the driver of GE's future growth when other businesses, like power, turn down.

But the note is in awe of Welch: 'Fixing Honeywell will call upon a lot of GE's resources, but... GE has done this sort of thing before,' Terrile wrote.' She added: 'The deal seems so much (a) a Jack deal... and (b) will be the thing that investors focus on until it is done... that the succession story becomes much smaller.'

With 3,000 miles perspective, UK analysts are not so sure. ABN Amro's Sandy Morris said: 'There are "yesses" about this. Perhaps Honeywell's automation will allow GE to develop its home products division, for example with fridges that can read barcodes and so on. But nobody has ever demonstrated to me that cockpits (Honeywell's Avionics) and engines (GE) have natural synergies. I'm sure if they had, people would have tried it.

'That said, GE is a phenomenally powerful company with a phenomenal growth record. The question is, is this the best thing it can find to do with its capital, or is it a sign that the momentum is finally beginning to go?'

First it was petrol. Next it was trains. Last week it was the turn of planes to prompt a crisis for the Government. Following in the wake of the Hatfield crash and the fuel protests that brought motorised Britain to a standstill, last Thursday saw its attempt to sell off 51 per cent of Britain's National Air Traffic Control System (Nats) rejected by the House of Lords .

The vote to delay the sale until after the next election won all-party support and came a day after Tony Blair refused to back down on the public-private partnership policy. The Government has pledged to reverse the change in the Commons before sending it back to the Lords.

Labour peer Lord Brett questioned the scheme's safety and disagreed with Blair that PPP was the only way to attract future investment in the system. Other ways - a public trust, for example - could do it without the 'conflict of interest' private firms might bring with them.

Within the wider context of air traffic control the vote against the UK scheme - under which 5 per cent would be sold to staff - was seen by many in the industry as a blessing. There are two reasons for this. First, Nats was a UK-only solution and airlines and aircraft manufacturers are far more interested in programmes that integrate airspace over continents rather than compartmentalising them. Only in this way can the growing congestion in the skies be eased.

Second, Nats paid little attention to the technological possibilities that a full modernisation of air traffic control systems should include. This, according to those who promote these solutions, is so as to ensure that the huge forecast increases in air travel can be controlled.

The International Airline Trade Association (IATA) points out that air traffic volumes rise by 5 to 6 per cent a year, and double every 10 years. The worst affected parts are north-east US and Europe, where volumes have shot up.

Airlines have been lobbying for change, particularly in Europe. Continental air traffic control systems are grossly inefficient, they contend. The reasons are partly political - individual states are loath to cede control of their airspace - and as a result Europe has more than 40 main traffic management centres to America's four. They are also technical - a plethora of different ground-based systems have grown up, sucking in investment.

Reforms proposed by IATA include more co-operation between nations in managing pan-European airspace, rationalisation of the ATC centres, a co-ordinated strategy to create more capacity in the skies, and liberalisation - not privatisation - of ATC. Airlines are desperate for more capacity. But they believe a satellite future is some way off in Europe.

'A solution can only be found by individual governments becoming co-operative, allowing others to operate through their airspace and not going out to pursue their own schemes for liberalisation or increasing capacity without co-ordination,' said a spokeswoman. Nats would clearly have failed on these criteria.

Alongside the geographical and structural issues are technological ones. The UK, like other European countries, has invested billions in state-of-the-art radar control facilities. This, say some in the aerospace industry, is missing the point. There needs to be a generational leap in technology to a satellite-run system.

The importance of technology depends on your future strategy. As far as the two major aircraft manufacturers are concerned, these could not be more different. Airbus sees the future in traffic-light mega-airliners such as its A3XX superjumbo, which can land 800 people a time at international hubs. The plane itself is part of the solution, thinning out the clutter of smaller aircraft.

Boeing, on the other hand, sees the future in traffic-heavy 'fragmentation' - more smaller planes flying higher-value short-haul routes to airports closer to travellers' final destinations. Here the planes are part of the problem: contributing to a lack of airway capacity.

As Boeing's chief operating officer, Harry Stonecipher, said last week at a meeting in London: 'The problem has got to be solved, otherwise growth in air travel slows, and that unpicks our company's airplane business.'

Boeing considered bidding for Nats but decided against it. It gave two reasons: it was a UK-only project, while the future required a Europe-wide one and it was not technologically radical enough. Nats, said Stonecipher 'is not about a solution. It is about nothing more than privatisation'.

At the meeting he announced that within a year Boeing planned to unveil a satellite-based scheme capable of total overhaul of air traffic control, managing it more efficiently than the current radar/satellite hybrids operating around the world and creating 50 per cent more space. The project would take five years before it could be rolled out. It will cost between $10bn and $20bn, of which Boeing is prepared to foot a significant proportion.

The fundamental difference between satellite and radar is this: radar tracks from the ground, plotting accurately an aircraft's progress on to a screen every three seconds or so. Satellites rely on the plane sending them signals before relaying them to the controller's screen.

Satellite, which is already in use through the US government's military GPS system where radar is uneconomic and impractical, are potentially quicker and more accurate than radar - allowing more planes to fly.

A next-generation system would initially run on GPS satellites but would eventually need a dedicated fleet of new-generation satellites capable of greater accuracy and predictive power, since plotting an aircraft's future course is as vital as knowing where it is now.

GPS can place aircraft to within 7 metres of their position. Fine on remote segments of long-haul journeys, where traffic densities are low, and where the satellite-based Future Air Navigation system has been rolled out.

But the key economic battleground will be shorter haul routes in Europe and north-east US. It is only here that the commercial disadvantage of congestion makes the multibillion dollar investment numbers add up behind satellite. Seven metres is not good enough.

Of course, it is Boeing, with its strategy of fragmentation, for which a new solution is most important. And the company intends to unveil its system next year in the US, where there are no political borders and less recent investment in terrestrial systems to hold it back.

The key problem then will be overcoming the scepticism of an industry more than ever aware of safety, and voters more wary about throwing money in the air now than they were during the Cold War, when the last 'Star Wars' initiative was pursued.

David Learmount, operations and safety editor of Flight International, says: 'The key thing is integrity. Radar doesn't lie. The controller knows a plane is where the dot on the screen says it is. But if the plane sends out a wrong signal to the satellite, the dot and the plane may not be the same at all.'

Boeing's key problem is to overcome such scepticism. If the system is workable, it will prove that Boeing was right to think small rather than big, as has Airbus.

It will also create an immensely powerful aerospace group, managing the airways as well as selling the planes to fill them.

Pantomime time

It's the gig everyone in the wacky world of Theatreland is just dying to get. At this time of year thesps up and down the land are anxiously phoning their agents and tearfully asking: 'Any news from Classic FM?' But now the agonising wait is over. The narrator of this year's musical panto - Sleeping Beauty - is to be Side Show Bob, also known as Ross Kemp, or Grant from Eastenders. Classic FM insiders deny Bob's amour, the well-known paedophile hunter and Screws ed Rebekah Wade, will take the role of Beauty. However, we have seen exclusive extracts from the script. In a break with tradition, Bob's somewhat gritty narrative loudly implores Beauty to 'JUST WAKE UP WILL YOU?' Those familiar with the rehearsals say in terms of pathos the scene matches Ross's memorable soliloquies following the death of Tiff.

Gossip corner

Talking of la Wade, the diary is sad to witness the tawdry goings-on surrounding Sun gossip hackette Marina Hyde. It was the Screws editrix who was responsible for sending Hyde to hack school at City University. But, Hyde, frog-marched out of the Sun after the Mekon found out she had been emailing the heart-throb who is Piers Morgan up to 10 times a day, did not do the whole course. Unfortunately, Hyde was not sent on a chunk of the course which no self-respecting journo should be without: ethics in journalism. Maybe, if Wade had exercised a bit more maternal control and forced Hyde to complete her studies, Fleet Street's gutter press would not have been dragged down by such unseemly shenanigans.

Chinese puzzle

The surprise news earlier this month that Gao Xingjuan, the veteran exiled Chinese dissident novelist and playwright, had been awarded the Nobel prize for literature had many of the scribbling world's finest scratching their heads in bewilderment. Gao's work has, up until now, been recognised only by those in the know and even they were somewhat perplexed. But not for much longer. The £615,000 prize will focus attention on what has been a remarkable life. Gao, currently classed as an 'unperson' by the Chinese authorities, had to flee Beijing in 1983 for fear of imprisonment. His novel, Soul Mountain, chronicles the months after his departure. Gao's publisher must be delighted at the news. Except that HarperCollins, (prop R Murdoch) is not renowned for its commitment to publishing books that attack the Chinese authorities.

Five comes alive

So bye bye David Elstein, cerebral head of Channel 5. And a big hello to Dawn Airey, the woman who turned Channel Five into Channel Filth. It is salutary to learn that, despite the claim by Five's shareholders to be hurt by their reputations as semi-pornographers, when the crunch came and they had to decide between Airey and Elstein, the phwoar factor won through. Don't feel sorry for Elstein, who departs with zillions in bonuses. No, instead feel sorry for the Daily Mail, which has waged a protracted and vicious attack on Airey, whom it sees as the antithesis of family values. Middle England suffers another devastating blow.

Boeing, the world's leading aircraft manufacturer, has criticised the Government's determination to sell off part of the UK air traffic control system. The US firm says the plan offers no solution to the problem of an ever-increasing number of planes in European airspace.

Seattle-based Boeing had been pondering the merits of joining the bidding for the 46 per cent of the National Air Traffic Services (NATS) being made available to a 'strategic' private sector partner . It decided against a bid because it did not consider the scheme addressed the congestion problem.

Harry Stonecipher, Boeing's chief executive, said the privatisation plan was 'not about a solution [to congestion]. As I understand it there it no fundamental change.'

'We think there is a total European solution, as opposed to a UK solution.'

Stonecipher's comments come at a critical time for the £500 million NATS sell-off, as a cross-party coalition of peers last week voted by 112 to 90 to delay the project from next March until after the next general election.

The vote puts pressure on the Government's Transport Bill, which includes measures to tackle the rail industry. There is speculation it may drop the sale to save the rest of the bill, although the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions has maintained that it will press ahead.

The congestion problems are acute for both airlines and plane manufacturers. The more crowded the skies, the less attractive flying becomes, particularly in valuable short-haul markets such as Europe.

Stonecipher said Boeing plans to unveil a satellite-based system capable of a total overhaul of air traffic management across continents. However, Europe was too fragmented a market in which to launch the system, he added. Political and technical barriers prevented it from being an immediate prospect.

Boeing's plan is to launch it first in the US next year.
