I'd somehow missed out on the Heather Mills phenomenon, having only the vaguest sense of her as a tabloid-dweller poised at the outer limits of Dianaville with easy access to the Beckham ring road. Last Sunday on Stars and Their Lives, in a breathy whirlwind of alliteration, Carol Vorderman helped fill in the gaps - 'She's gorgeous but she's gutsy too! She's the Geordie with the giant heart! The beauty who battles against the bad times! The model who became a model campaigner' - when she introduced the celebrity amputee and consort to Sir Paul McCartney on ITV's answer to This Is Your Life .

I couldn't work out how this inscrutably blank-faced Barbie-blonde (see, it's catching) ticked, even while friends from Chris Eubank to Richard Branson to the Duchess of Kent testified to her all-round gutsy goodness, her toughness and non-conformity. Heather accessorised herself with a dry Geordie wit, thereby unsettling the audience who didn't know quite how to respond to stuff like 'I thought: what's my leg doing over there? I've just bought those trainers! I'll never get the blood off!'

But then McCartney came on to kiss her and tell us he loved her, which was like watching the post-coital analysis in an edition of Celebrity Blind Date . Macca had improbably starry eyes, youthfully-tinted hair and described his girlfriend as 'a very beautiful true fine momma'. He looked about as besotted as a man can be without having to display a Do Not Disturb sign. 'I always had this dream of a knight in shining armour,' said Heather.

Carol told the couple that there is a lot of goodwill towards them, 'isn't there?!'. 'Mmm!' muttered the audience. But, and I can't put my finger on quite why this should be, given Macca's recent pain and Heather's tireless charity work, Carol was wrong; there isn't quite as much goodwill towards them as they'd like. 'People that are jealous of us, or bitter, you look at those people's lives and they give and do nothing for anyone else. But people who like us are giving, nice people,' explained Mills, which presumably leaves most of us in Nowhere-Man's-land, slightly bemused by the combination of Heather's strident sanctimony and Sir Paul's slavering.

Funnily enough, Pride was the first of the sins to be tackled in... well, The Sins, BBC1's new go-on!-guess-how-many-parts series, in which Pete Postlethwaite plays Len, an ex-getaway driver determined to go straight. I couldn't take my eyes off that spin-dried Sinatra face, in which sweetness and menace seem to fight for control of his features. So much so, that scenes without Postlethwaite faltered slightly, not through any fault of the script or the acting, but just because Pete fills the screen with so much mutable gravitas.

Frank Finlay came close, though, as Len's Uncle Irwin, a funeral director contemplating retirement, regretful that 'there is no obvious replacement chomping at the funereal bit' and operating just a few doors up the road from the Hammer House of Horror: 'I have some lungs to drain, but I can work quite happily while you rummage around.' After his turn as Dylan (love-of-my-life) Moran's evil father-in-law in How Do You Want Me?, Finlay is rather belatedly cornering the market in menacing campery - which is odd given that he was doing it brilliantly as far back as Bouquet of Barbed Wire .

Len's sin manifested at a party thrown to celebrate his release from a four-year stretch, where he told his crime cronies they were 'dullards' and proclaimed his freshly minted middle-classness: 'I live in Paradise Drive, I've had a letter published in the Telegraph, one of my daughters is up at Oxford', which, predictably, went down like a pair of concrete wellies, particularly with his family. Suddenly, Len's wife (Geraldine James) couldn't get her regular table at Mario's ('Am I or am I not Len Green's wife?' 'Len Green is not Len Green any more,' shrugged Mario) and 'in the light of recent developments' her credit was revoked at the local boutique.

Meanwhile, Len was off to the Job Centre, demanding 'proper, stimulating, middle-aged, middle-England legal employment'. The Sins is deliciously wordy, funny and even had a great car chase - very rare on TV, where even Grand Prix look as though everyone's pootling around the M25 in third gear. Next week sees Len working, inevitably, as an undertaker while struggling with Covetousness, particularly in relation to top-of-the-range, fully-loaded hearses. Can't wait.

BBC2's Marion and Geoff is a 10-part series of 10-minute dramatic monologues by Keith, minicab driver, divorcee and owner of a selection of Alan Partridge's cast-off sweaters (Steve Coogan is one of the show's producers). Last week saw the halfway mark, which is as good a place as any to ponder Keith's swiftly unravelling grip on what little is left of his sanity. The Marion and Geoff of the title are, respectively, Keith's ex-wife and her new husband, who live in Cardiff with Keith's two young sons, while Keith lives in London but regularly drives through the night accompanied by binoculars, a rifle (with telescopic sight) and toys for the children: 'I thought the Action Man might be too violent but, like his mother says, he's a very violent child.'

What initially looked like tragic stoicism in the face of complete rejection (re Geoff: 'I don't feel like I've lost a wife, I've gained a friend!') is proving to be a dangerously thin veneer. Last week, Keith told us how he'd gone to see Father Paul, a pastor - he said: 'You don't need the Church, Keith, you need a bloody good solicitor' - and though we are another five fraught weeks away, the dénouement looks likely to inspire a nationwide mini-cab boycott.

Luckily, young Sonia Jackson got a lift to hospital in a black cab when she gave birth, unexpectedly, to Martin Fowler's daughter in Thursday's EastEnders. This was a disappointing episode not least because too many storylines jostled for our attention. Wasn't a teenage girl going into labour without knowing she was pregnant considered enough to sustain 30 minutes of sudsy excitement? Given that Natalie Cassidy is such a good little actress and Sonia such a sympathetic character, they could both have been allowed to hog the show. Instead, the drama was squandered by having Mo Harris play midwife, and constant cutting to the rows between Melanie and Steve, trysts between Frank and Pat, a showdown between Pauline and Martin and, to top it all, an unnecessarily drunk, and therefore pantomimic, Dot Cotton.

These days, EastEnders is often distracted from what, in soap terms at least, used to be a laudable concentration span in which plotlines could develop and thrive. At the moment, the cast is too big and too starry and so, perhaps, too demanding of the spotlight. Poor Sonia - she could hardly hear her baby crying over all that din.

Akram Khan Lilian Baylis Theatre, London EC1
Swan Lake ROH, London WC2

Akram Khan dances in freefall, composed and intense, hanging in there for dear life. Where ballet dancers try to escape gravity, he ignores it. Thanks to his training in the Kathak tradition of Indian dance, he can scoot around space like a jump-cut edit. He's moved before you can blink.

Khan has launched his own company (now touring) with a trio, Rush, following his concentrated solo, Fix. The solo is addictive, changing subtly each time he has performed it over the past year. Last week's account was the most ascetic yet, more a Sufi meditation than a journey of discovery.

The question of whether Khan can transfer his skills to other bodies is part-answered by Rush. He takes motifs from Fix - spins, falls and rolls - and formalises them into rhythmic patterns. At first, you watch only him; then the structure takes over. Gwyn Emberton and Moya Michael contribute their own qualities; where Khan floats, they flail themselves into weightlessness. Rush feels like a work in progress, ready for further elaboration.

Anthony Dowell's last season as artistic director of the Royal Ballet opened with his 1987 production of Swan Lake. No doubt the first thing his successor, Ross Stretton, will do is replace it with his own. Maybe then we'll be sorry to lose Dowell's version.

But since the last Swan Lake we saw on the Opera House stage in summer was the Kirov's, it is obvious how much the Royal Ballet has been missing over the years. Compared with the Kirov's classic account of the white acts, Dowell's looks decadent, sentimental. His swan-maidens are fluffy, lakeside creatures, their abstract patterns blurred by fluttery dresses and a flock of swan-children, cute, minute and in the way.

This soft-edged corps bears no relation to the strikingly athletic Odette of Darcey Bussell, a bird-woman whose pinions have to be held down by her determined suitor (Roberto Bolle). She dances with admirable power, then mars her clean sweep by adding flapping hands and a pained expression. Instead of moving in a sustained flow, as Kirov swan queens do, Bussell goes from one pose to another. She end-stops the dance phrases by holding balances as long as she can.

It is an approach that works triumphantly in Act III, where her Odile is boldly alluring. Bolle's Siegfried succumbs without a qualm. A discreet partner and excellent dancer, Bolle needs to assert himself more forcefully to complement Bussell's Olympian magnetism.

Johan Persson, making his debut on Wednesday with Tamara Rojo, portrayed a feckless Euro-princeling, obstinately falling for the wrong girl.

Rojo's Odile was wicked in the modern sense, whipping off triple fouettés and shooting seductive glances from under her dark brows. As Odile, she was all of a piece; as Odette in Act II, she seemed to be giving two interpretations - her own and the Royal Ballet's.

Everything came together in the last act, where she and the swans, companions in distress, finally inhabited the same world. Act IV is the climax of this production, instead of the coda, a sign of how skewed towards soppiness Dowell's vision has become.

In the Mood For Love (98mins, PG) Directed by Wong Kar-Wai; starring Tony Leung, Maggie Cheung

Are you In the Mood For Love? It sounds like a romantic comedy - Ryan and Hanks, even Fred and Ginger - but there is nothing remotely comic here. This love is intricate, consuming and elegiac. And, though the mood is essentially European - say mid-career Truffaut, with a whisper of Brief Encounter - the setting is far away in the Hong Kong of the early Sixties. Wong Kar-Wai, chameleon amongst great directors, has done it again.

Tony Leung Chiu-Wai is Mr Chow, a thirtysomething journalist with a pretty wife. Maggie Cheung Man-Yuk is Mrs Chow, a super secretary married to a travelling businessman. The couples find rooms to live in adjoining flats. Slowly, it dawns on Leung and Cheung that their increasingly absent partners are having an affair. Slowly, Leung begins his pursuit of the wronged wife and she begins to descend into an agony of doubt. If she succumbs, will she be any better than her faithless husband?

Wong Kar-Wai does everything: action movies, cop movies, epics, often with a French new-wave feel of improvisation. Here, there is none of that. Instead, we move meticulously from one little box to the next, from one poky room to the room next door. Other rooms in the apartment block are filmed down corridors or over shoulders; the only excursions beyond are into deserted streets where rain falls torrentially around the sheltering pair. Complete claustrophobia. We never see the faces of the adulterous husband or his mistress, only their backs: they are ciphers throwing Leung and Cheung into starker relief.

Does that sound a trifle dour? It isn't. The family who rent Cheung her room are warm and effusive, always offering food and companionship. Leung's hoary journalist mate is rounded and jolly. There is human life just across the landing or at the office; the characters are rooted in place and time - but that time, too, matters. Falling in love in the Hong Kong of four decades ago isn't a quick, modern fling. You feel the brooding disapproval of a more traditional Chinese society. Contacts must be secret, emotions hidden. Celia Johnson looks out of the railway carriage window. Upper lips stiffen and then quiver. When Cheung is trapped - innocently enough - in Leung's bedroom overnight, because others are playing mah-jong outside, there's no question of a quick roll on the bed. Cheung lies there alone, imprisoned by inhibition.

Wong Kar-Wai is never entirely unobtrusive. The director's presence remains constant - sometimes playing jokes, like rehearsals of the farewell speeches Cheung will make to her husband, which appear, for a moment, to be the real thing. But that constant presence merely focuses us more hypnotically on the central relationship; and upon a particular sequence of months and passions locked away, resistance eroding as the mood takes hold.

It doesn't work completely. Leung and Cheung are two of China's most fêted stars, one stubby, battered and thoughtfully bemused, the other sinuous and tortured. They hold the screen and the still, silent Leung is especially hypnotic as he calculates and manipulates. But Cheung has an almost impossibly testing role. Can she make us, as twenty-first-century spectators, comprehend and share her inner turmoil? Can she become somebody we not only understand intellectually, but weep for in her desperate dilemma of the soul?

Maybe Truffaut could have got that from Nathalie Baye, because her face is infinitely expressive and part of a world we understand. Cheung cannot quite convey that. She agonises, but she can't draw us in. The gap between eras and cultures is too great. The background score, by Mike Galasso, plonks away, sometimes Nat King Cole, sometimes second-hand Michel Legrand, so that you know you ought to understand. But no - you can see the suffering, yet you don't feel it. A love story without the hint of tear.

But for all that this is an accomplished and memorable film, one that Wong Kar-Wai fought to finish through two years of censorship and Eastern financial crisis. Why should the censors have worried? There is no sex here, no sweaty coupling. This is love pursued, love won, love lost; love as a mingling of minds and calculation; love as regret. The chameleon called love.

Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (90mins, 18) Directed by Joe Berlinger; starring Kim Director, Jeffrey Donovan
It Was an Accident (100mins, 18) Directed by Metin Hüseyin; starring Max Beesley, Thandie Newton
I Could Read the Sky (86 mins, 15) Directed by Nichola Bruce; starring Dermot Healy

Sometimes, one and one don't make two. Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, has next to nothing of the Project that set cash registers ringing. Not the same cast, the same director, the same style or any continuation - if that were possible - of the same story. This is tosh of an altogether lower order. There isn't even, since you ask, a book of shadows.

Forget the artful triumph of what we must now call Blair Witch 1, the hand-held cameras which followed three students into the woods of Black Hills, Maryland, and, half-way between documentary and drama, appeared to chronicle their vanishing, victims of a phantom we never saw. If that was docuhorror, this is schlocku-horror.

It doesn't start like that. Joe Berlinger, who specialises in filming real murder mysteries, has had the bright notion of taking the actual fame that the Project brought to the village of Burkittsville and sending five more potential victims into the woods on a kind of idiotic guided tour. Cue in two minutes or so of genuinely funny cod interviews with local residents. Hope rises.There weren't many jokes in BW1. Hope falls. The quintet are standard freaks for the teenage market. They reach the house at the heart of darkness, they come out intact: but then, in the old warehouse which Jeffrey Donovan, their loopy tour guide uses as his Blair Witch mail shop, the curse of the Black Hills catches up with them. Standard freaks, standard mayhem.

Where the chill of the original came from not knowing, not seeing, Berlinger jolts the screen with blood and guts. Where the sparse, $30,000 production values of BW1 were integral to its queasy credibility, here cash and computer effects rule this dotty roost.

Our unfortunate five give us nothing to identify with. Donovan's Jeff is fresh out of an asylum, but nothing's ultimately made of his supreme flakiness. Kim Director wears white pancake make-up straight out of The Munsters and has the occasional gift of prophesy, except where her own fate's concerned; Erica Leerhsen is a student witch much given to hopping round in the nude; Tristan Skyler and Stephen Barker are dopey young lovers. None of them is going to win an Oscar. When Donovan protests out loud that 'I don't understand this' the audience gurgles with instant derision.

Still, it will doubtless make a few million - and deserve to, not entirely for its effrontery. Berlinger knows how to keep the action zipping along. Arch references to movies past and present are scattered liberally. If BW1 hadn't existed, BW2 might have passed muster in the Saturday night stalls. Go expecting to be kept awake, but not to be amazed or chilled.

So to two films from closer to home, both derived from successful novels, both blessed with an Arts Council grant. Why are the financial arbiters of culture favouring It Was an Accident? Does somebody up there in Great Peter Street think that British film is perishing for lack of London gangster movies? They might as well erect a statue of Ray Winstone in Trafalgar Square.

To be fair, this Accident, contrived by Ol Parker from Jeremy Cameron's book, has some promising things going for it. Belly laughs for a start; a Runyonesque version of Walthamstow street life for another. Nicky Burkett, played by Chjwetel Ejiofor, is back on those streets after four years in the slammer.

He wants to go straight and shack up with a policeman's daughter (Thandie Newton), but villains keep getting in his way. There's Mickey Cousins (Max Beesley), your original blond idiot; there's Rameez (Sidh Solanki), your Asian Mr Big; there's Fitch (James Bolam), who 'used to drive for the Krays'.

The first half bowls along nicely, full of neat touches. The cops, save for Newton's thoughtful black dad (Hugh Quarshie), are Keystone galumphers. Ejiofor, of course, has a wonderfully lippy kid by a discarded partner. The dodgy flats, motors and market tradesmen combine to make this Walthamstow a fun place to be. Metin Hüseyin (from Common as Muck ) knows how to stage comic setpieces. Where does it all go wrong? Pacing, tone, language.

You can't keep going as fast as this without a break. What works for a TV sitcom doesn't work for a film three times as long. The haste becomes frenetic, and thus disjunct. And this is a Brit gangster effort (without Sadie Frost for once) so, naturally, it can't be all laughs, can it? You have to have a bit of - you know - thumping and shooting and smashing. Bring on the gratuitous violence. Exit the light touch.

Language? I should effing say so, every effing 15 seconds. It ain't a matter of prudery, mate, it just gets effing boring in the effing end.

The great unresolved question is how Thandie Newton, luminously svelte in Mission Impossible 2 , here turns up as Ehofor's relatively chaste bit of fluff in an anorak, but her very presence makes the wider point. Newton is a considerable actress who can play a human being (among many other things). Ol Parker's script gives here little to do but frown and look disapproving. That's not an accident - it's an effing waste of effing talent.

Those who like their art with a capital C, as in Council, will find I Could Read the Sky more their evocative fix. It's an adaptation, by Nichola Bruce, of the 'photo-novel' by Timothy O'Grady and Steve Pyke which was Gerry Adams's best book of 1997. Dermot Healy, the distinguished Irish novelist, has the central acting role. He is old, creaky Irish labourer, and he lives in a London garret, shuffling the bare boards, remembering.

He remembers the white-washed cottage in the green fields of home. He remembers his mum and dad and the poverty that forced him to come, with thousands of others, to the building sites of England. He remembers the wife who died and the mate who died sleeping in a giant sewage pipe and his mother who died, black with cancer when they did the post-mortem, and the father whose grave he was left to disinter in the mud and rain. All this with the photos of the book opened out into landscapes and small scenes from the past, performed by Ireland's finest, like Stephen Rea.

It is a tour de force from Healy, a ginger, shambling wreck who speaks the almost-poetry with arresting precision. Beautiful words; beautiful music, from Iarla O'Lionaird; beautiful moving pictures from Nichola Bruce. Too beautiful, too relentlessly melancholic? That's the trouble.

The photo-novel works so brilliantly because you can linger over O'Grady's prose and set it against Pyke's photographs, choosing your own pace and time, letting the images grows. Contract that into 86 minutes of movie narrative, though, and the obligatory returns to Healy's garret become a bit of chore, without light and shade. You either want to know more or less - and the death of his inevitably beautiful wife (Maria Doyle Kennedy) feels merely gratuitous, one more awful thing piled on top.

For all the novelty of its form, we've been here before amid the Irish mists of exile. Somehow, I wanted to be told something new.

Tantalus Denver Center for the Performing Arts, Colorado

Why Denver? After 15 years of labour, John Barton, director and co-founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company, produces a massive cycle of plays. It's based on Greek mythology, which means that it touches on almost every issue flying around the twenty-first century: vengeance after war, the chances of a just peace, the impossibility of assigning blame and the point at which a beauty becomes an icon. Stephen Daldry declares he would rip out the seating in the Old Vic in order to stage it.

Peter Hall, Barton's life-long friend who becomes, together with his son, Edward, director of the cycle proclaims that if he were running the RSC he'd 'scrap some of the repertory' in order to put it on. But when the premiere of Tantalus takes place it is hundreds of miles away, at the Denver Center for Performing Arts in Colorado.

Lack of cash meant that the RSC, who commissioned the piece, couldn't put it on. There was no room at the Dome. And no television company was prepared to stump up. This is a shaming indictment of British arts policy: avid for buildings; less concerned with what takes place inside them. But the move across the Atlantic turned out to be peculiarly apt. As if the Fates had been at work.

A play which shows the sacking of one civilisation and the making of another - Greece - was performed in a town whose glossy towers and silent gleaming malls are surrounded by the relics of faded glories, by old mining towns with names, such as Silver Plume, as evocative as Troy, though now their only gold hangs from aspen branches. It was acted by a cast of Americans and Britons in a place formed by Hispanic and Native American and pioneer cultures.

And Denver's craggy setting proved particularly piquant. Tantalus was punished by continual threat and constantly frustrated desire for betraying the gods. In Hades, grapes were dangled in front of his mouth and a rock was suspended precariously above him: in the Halls' production, you see sand drifting down and at crucial moments hear warning groans, as if an avalanche were about to launch itself on to the stage. Where better to acknowledge this stony menace than in a city shadowed by the Rockies?

It's a tribute to Tantalus that it wakes you up to such parallels.

And the tribute's the greater because Barton's enterprise has one foot in the academy. He has created his own version of the conduct and consequences of the Trojan War. He has drawn on ancient sources, though without using lines from classical drama. He has written in unrhymed verse, though the verse format isn't always detectable, or delectable. He has larded the dialogue with literary allusions ranging from Troilus and Cressida to The Importance of Being Earnest: 'One rape is a misfortune; two cause comment.'

Tantalus has been cut and edited by the directors. But its nine remaining plays - in which the playwright Colin Teevan is credited with providing some 'additional text' - still amount to a marathon: at Denver, they started at 10am and ended at 10.45pm. It is, remarked one member of the audience, 'such a dare to do something this long about something so old'.

A battery of surprises keeps the audience on its intellectual toes, not to say tantalised. The structure of the plays is unexpected: a series of cliffhangers, which Barton has described as soap-operatic. The dialogue switchbacks unpredictably from bleak to droll. The plot twists are startling: the Greeks sail off for Troy, but land up in Mysia; Helen is said not to have gone to Troy at all because that was another, more superficial Helen. And, alongside a reprisal of classical tragic themes - do human beings have any control over their own destinies? Are patterns of revenge imprinted through generations? - Barton charts his own concerns. Not least of these is the history of drama, a movement from storytelling to acting, which suggests that Ulysses started out as a bit of a fraud, and that Achilles's son was the first actor - getting himself up in drag in order to beguile the Trojans.

Some of this is exhilarating. There are terrific performances from the fluidly transforming (American) Analee Jefferies and from (British) Greg Hicks, as a wry Agamemnon and a tottering carnival Priam. Some of it is casually misogynistic: does Helen, in a world of adulterous men, have to be pure to be adored?

Some scenes are made more vital by the Halls' robust, sometimes gorgeous production: the Trojan women, about to be branded by their conquerors, appear in their red wedding dresses like the stumps of teeth; Mick Sands' dulcimers and drums ripple through the action; Dionysis Fotopoulos's design, a hemisphere of sand with a screen of smokey glass at its back, is transformed by Sumio Yoshii's lighting into a rippling underwater region.

Other episodes are made more ludicrous: it's bad enough that Barton's female chorus is required to behave like stooges teasing out information from a charismatic male poet. ('Yes he was a god-swan.' 'Which god was it?') But the clumpiness is increased by setting the scene on a Fifties-going-on-Sixties beach, with a gaggle of girls, clenched by bikinis and clutching transistors, desperately trying to look hip. Never can there have been so much explanation with so little clarity. It's a fluent, exciting production which is insufficiently peculiar.

It has spawned its own epic struggles. The artistic director of the Gate, Mick Gordon, was engaged to work with the Halls, but exited early. One actor was sacked; one left. Barton has described the performed version of his cycle as drastically condensed', and explains 'my own vision, however passionate may not necessarily be welcome'. He was not at the premiere.

Tantalus comes to the Lowry Centre in Salford in January, and then tours Britain.

Until last January, my 85-year-old widowed mother lived in her own suburban home. She was hospitalised with flu and assessed as needing full-time nursing care, as her family had known for some time. Since then, she has lived in a nearby, cheerful, friendly nursing home but as her strength has improved she has become more and more depressed at her situation to the point of needing medication.

Although her short-term memory loss and Parkinson's means that she can't sustain her thoughts, they clearly centre on: 'Why am I here?'

I know she feels that she has a right to be cared for by my brother or myself, just as she cared for her own mother-in-law for 10 years.

My brother and his wife live nearby but work full-time. My husband and I, while early retired, live six- and-a-half-hours' drive away in a remote location. When any of us visit her she clings to us and asks us to stay with her. I do not feel I could possibly offer her what she needs but I also feel I have abandoned her.

Please would you comment on all this?

W.A. of Pembrokeshire

A person who gives up her own concerns to look after another individual shows an awesome degree of philanthropy, which I for one could not match. Giving total care can be tough and heart-breaking, and virtue very seldom brings its own reward.

Everyone gets more selfish with passing years, progressive incapacity and narrowing horizons, and less able to see matters from another perspective. This defect is multiplied when there is encroaching senility. If you were to restructure your life to take on your mother's care, you could well find the task you had set yourself intolerably burdensome.

You might discover, as others have done, that your own marital relationship suffer to the point of collapse, and that even your own patience and good intentions break down in the face of unrelieved, infuriating, round-the-clock demands.

Instead, your mother is in a professionally-run home where the weight of caring is spread among several attendants who can hand over at the appropriate time, walk away, enjoy their own concerns, take a break, recharge their own batteries. Ask yourself: would your mother in, when fully compos mentis, have wanted you to give up all your retired comfort to dance attendance on her? I should abhor the idea of becoming that sort of drag on my children.

Sometimes, senility reproduces reflexes which are peculiar to early infancy, such as the clutching and clinging that you describe. They invoke similar responses in you as in young mothers, a stressful perception of the needs of this helpless being, and an urgent desire to meet them. The manipulation is not intentional but it is compelling.

Don't let the discomfort of your conscience drive you to take on an unreasonable task, but don't let it drive you away either. There is much you can do, visiting and adding to her comfort, being loving and cheerful, but firm.

With a rising proportion of elderly folk in the population and a government that distances itself from the responsibility of providing care for them, your problem is going to become increasingly common. If it is expected that old people are to be looked after by the next generation, there must be a cut-off point; people in their seventies should not be full-time carers for people in their nineties.

I've an idea that we should reactivate the concept of national service for young people after leaving school; two years of caring for old people in various circumstances.

The old and the young meld very well together, and exposure to the needs of others is excellent training, and the scheme would provide huge potential employment at many levels for organisers and supervisors. Some such innovation will be needed if present trends in longevity continue.

Next week's dilemma is from A.M. of Lincoln

I am in the process of divorcing my husband of five years. We have a two-year-old daughter. When we first separated, he came to see her regularly but his visits have now become less frequent because, he says, he cannot bear seeing me.

So far, I have done nothing to encourage him because, although my rational self is keen for him to stay in contact with us so that he and our daughter can build a relationship, there's a part of me that would not be sorry to see him fade away.

He has an alcohol problem which has worsened over the years, and I worry what kind of a role model he will be and whether our daughter will be able to cope with his problems.

Should I encourage him to see her regularly or let him quietly drift away?

Paul Merton loves the way people come up to him and say, 'You look different - oh you've had your hair cut!' as if having his hair cut could explain his great weight loss. As you can see on the new series of Have I Got News For You, he really does look different, no longer puffy and dishevelled but positively svelte, a shimmering vision of elegance almost like - well, not quite like - Angus Deayton. Two years ago he ballooned to a terrifying 17 stone and was frightened by his own passport photograph. So since then he's been eating sensibly and laying off the beer. In the past few months, he's also stopped eating wheat or anything containing gluten because he found it made him lethargic, and the result is that he has lost three stone.

Anyway, he looks good - but disconcertingly different to the Paul Merton one knows and loves from television. I was quite worried about meeting him because I always got the impression from Have I Got News (not so much from Room 101) that he could be a bit chippy, sullen, taciturn - I feared it might be a case of me asking ever longer, daffier questions and him giving ever shorter, surlier replies. Whereas in fact he was almost puppyishly friendly, sunny, hello birds, hello trees, and eager to share his enthusiasms, especially his enthusiasm for comedy.

He once said, 'I could have been the world's biggest comedy anorak, the most boring man imaginable' and although I wouldn't say boring, there are certain questions such as 'Why do you admire Buster Keaton?' which bring out the inner trainspotter to an alarming degree. As a boy, he used to watch silent comedies on his own projector and analyse every scene, but he's still doing it now - he told me that recently he's bought all the films of Charlie Chaplin on DVD and has been watching them in sequence from the first in 1915 to the last in 1967, tracing the development of his technique.

The essential, all-encompassing difference between Paul Merton on telly and Paul Merton in real life is that the real-life version is obviously a happy man. After a rocky couple of years when his marriage to Caroline Quentin broke up, he is now happily settled with his new partner, Sarah Parkinson, and declares: 'We are together for the rest of our lives.' And anyway he is happy because, 'Look, I'm sitting here having lunch in a nice restaurant [the Caprice] on a Monday when I could have been in the civil service office in Tooting - I mean, life is good. And on a day like today when I can see people getting on the tube and I can see their drawn faces and I think, They're going to get into their offices - "Morning, Lorraine", "Morning, Mr Hennessy" - and that's what they're doing till Friday, I think: Well, just by not having to do that, I'm already ahead of the game.'

Last month he and Sarah went on holiday to the Maldives and 'We went to this desert island - they take you there in a boat, and give you a picnic basket and a walkie-talkie - and had a little ceremony between the two of us, with nobody else there. So it was very romantic and we did it at midday on October fifth, so that's 5/10/2000 to make it memorable.' But why not marry properly? 'Oh because Sarah's not keen on the whole church/state thing, and I'm kind of like-minded, really. Why not just two people on a desert island? We got married in nature rather than in church.'

Sarah is 38 and the daughter of an actor called Robin Parkinson. She used to be an actress but told Paul particularly to tell me that she no longer wishes to be described as that - she is now a writer-producer. She co-wrote and associate-produced his new film The Suicidal Dog (of which more later), and is also producing a radio series called Catholics in Comedy in which Paul will interview other comedians who were raised as Catholics. (There are surprisingly many of them - Kathy Burke, Julian Clary, Lily Savage, Steve Coogan, Caroline Aherne - quite apart from what he calls 'the Irish contingent'.) Obviously they plan to work together as much as possible.

They met in 1995 when Paul Merton and Caroline Quentin were doing a three-month run of The Live Bed Show in London, and Sarah was Caroline's understudy. (She never got to play the role because Caroline was never ill.) At that stage, he says, they were 'just talking'. But then in 1997 his marriage to Quentin broke up. Quentin told me that she was completely shocked and mystified at the time - 'I didn't know my marriage was going wrong till it ended, really.' They had been married seven years since Paul proposed on bended knee by the statue of Eros in Piccadilly Circus and they seemed in many ways a perfect couple. But after Quentin's career took off with Men Behaving Badly, their various work commitments meant they were often apart. When they announced their separation in April 1997, they were hounded by the tabloids for several weeks and The Mirror even sent a pseudo-buyer to their house to photograph their bedroom. Merton is still pretty bitter about all that. He and Quentin have always been careful not to say anything hurtful about each other in interviews, and they are friendly on the rare occasions when they meet. Last year she had a baby by Sam Farmer, a television researcher.

Do Paul and Sarah hope to have children? 'Yes, well, we could, we will. We'll have to wait and see really. But I mean - we're doing what we should be doing on a very regular basis, so it's in the lap of the gods! And yes, I could have a child now, because I'm financially secure for the foreseeable future and I don't have expensive tastes anyway. If it had happened when I was 23, 24 it would have been a disaster because I'd have had to give up doing comedy, or attempting to do comedy. But now - yes, maybe.' And Sarah would like children, too? 'Yes - I thought she should get involved at some stage, and the planning stage seemed a good stage to begin!'

Paul and Sarah live in considerable style in a listed Georgian house in Parson's Green, Fulham, where he says nobody recognises him 'because they're all too posh to watch television - the only people who recognise me are van drivers passing through'. It is actually less than a mile from where he was born 43 years ago, but Fulham has come up in the world, as has he. His father was a tube train driver, his mother a nurse, and they lived in a council flat. He was very shy as a boy but hooked on comedy from an early age. He thinks the two are connected - he says most comedians are shy. 'I was never one to go up to someone as a five- or six-year-old and say, "Hello, my name's Paul, will you be my friend?" But I found if I did an impression of the PE teacher or whatever and people laughed, then they did like me, and so then they started talking to me, rather than me making the initial overture and then maybe being rebuffed. They come to you already happy, you know?'

Even as a small child, he really studied comedy. He would watch Sunday at the London Palladium and ignore the singers and dancers but 'If a comic came on - it didn't matter how appalling he was - I would watch, fascinated by the whole process. I got into Laurel and Hardy very early on, Charlie Chaplin, Marx Brothers, the Goons on the radio. Monty Python started when I was about 12, Tony Hancock I loved, and I read PG Wodehouse - I loved comedy in all its forms. I was an avid consumer of comedy. I think there was something in my head whereby I was trying to learn as much as I could about it without actually doing it. I read every book about Buster Keaton and Chaplin to see how they worked - it's all about dedication, tunnel vision, pursuit of perfection, getting the gag right.'

But he planned his career slowly, carefully, deliberately, because he didn't want to be famous for five minutes, he wanted to last . His dream is to be like Bob Monkhouse, still working in his seventies. So after school (two A levels), he went to work for the civil service in the Tooting employment office, and wrote scripts in his spare time and sent them off to the BBC. But he eventually realised that they would not buy scripts from unknowns - he had to make his name first as a performer, which meant doing stand up. And he knew he wouldn't have the energy, or perhaps the will, to do that while doing a nine-to-five job. So he left the civil service on 29 February 1980 - he chose the date deliberately so he would remember it - and signed on.

'It was a bizarre existence I led in my early twenties - that cliché of the comedian who goes out and entertains a roomful of people and then goes home to a lonely bedsit was unbelievably poignant for me because that was exactly what I was doing. I had periods of real loneliness. But it was something I'd chosen to do, it hadn't been imposed on me, so I could never complain. And I didn't have any dependents or anything to worry about other than just living on the dole and doing good gigs, but then coming back and still being on my own.' Did he have girlfriends? 'A couple here and there, but not really. I was never one to do the chasing - I was always very shy - and even if some girl had come up and said hello, I couldn't have said, "Come back to the bedsit" - she would have seen it and said goodbye.'

He was often depressed - he remembers spending whole days in bed because he couldn't face getting up. 'I always had to battle that thing with confidence - and it took me two years after I left the civil service to get on stage at the Comedy Store. But again, that was partly because I wanted it so much, because to have a great ambition and then find out you're no good at it is potentially quite soul-destroying. So I was postponing or delaying the moment of truth.' But in April 1982 he did his act at the Comedy Store and got a standing ovation and walked all the way home to Streatham in a daze of happiness.

Gradually, he built up his bookings and his fees and by 1987 had saved enough to hire a hall and put on his own show at the Edinburgh Festival. It got terrific reviews - but the day after the first night he broke his leg playing football, went to hospital, developed a pulmonary embolism (which almost killed him) and caught hepatitis A, so he was out of work for months. This led to another of his big decisions - he felt he had served his apprenticeship on the comedy circuit, it was time to make the leap into television. He wrote scripts for Julian Clary, appeared on Whose Line Is It Anyway? and in 1989 was commissioned to write his own Paul Merton show for Channel 4.

But now again, as when he broke his leg, he wobbled on the brink of success - only this was much more than a wobble. It was a mental illness that put him in the Maudsley psychiatric hospital for six weeks, though even now he yelps when I refer to it as a nervous breakdown and says it was not a nervous breakdown - it was a 'manic episode' caused by a combination of overwork and anti-malaria pills. 'I just think it was a sort of manic excitement, really, because everything was happening and it was going really well. I felt that it was a good thing. Because, apart from just before I went into the Maudsley, I felt good, I felt alive, I felt alert, I was full of energy. It was the people around me who were getting worried - I wasn't too bothered. I thought: I'm achieving everything.'

But his friends were worried because he was talking non-stop, almost gibbering, and working 24 hours a day. He suffered what he thought was a heart attack during a run-through of Whose Line Is It Anyway? and they called a doctor, who told him he was hyperventilating and must take some rest. But of course he couldn't rest because he was far too busy. He developed paranoia, thinking that people were talking about him behind his back and that he was being followed everywhere by Freemasons. One day he went to the corner shop and thought everyone was looking at him oddly, and the shopkeeper was reading things about him off his credit card. 'I remember coming out of the shop and running down the side road back to the flat and I had a filmic image of all the curtains twitching.'

His girlfriend persuaded him to go to the Maudsley but he discharged himself after a few days because he was desperate to finish writing his Channel 4 series. But then he broke down again and was admitted for six weeks and put on Largactyl. He recalls the embarrassment of going to group therapy sessions with serious schizophrenics and people who had attacked strangers with knives when his only problem, he thought, was that his Channel 4 series had been postponed. He also remembers when one of the fellow patients committed suicide and he volunteered to speak at his funeral but someone shouted something. 'And suddenly I was in stand-up mode. I had to fight the urge to use a putdown, to say, "Oh I remember when I had my first pint of lager..." It was a very black comic moment.'

But he also remembers the precise moment when he started to get better. It was a Saturday evening, a friend came to visit him and 'What I wanted was for somebody to hug me. But he, being a typical middle-class male, was keeping his distance. And his emotional detachment made me feel even more alone. When he went away, I felt so lonely, I howled, like animals cry.' But that howl of pain was a sort of catharsis, and after that he recovered quickly. Even so, he was reluctant for many years to talk about his stay in the Maudsley. It was only last year, on The South Bank Show, that he fully came clean, and also returned to the Maudsley for the first time, to open a new garden for the patients. He has had no manic episodes since, but has been careful to pace himself and not take on more work than he could handle.

Ironically, the Channel 4 series he had literally driven himself mad to write was not a great success. But it hardly mattered because by then Have I Got News For You had started, and made him a star. It is now in its 10th year, and has just shifted to BBC1. One year Merton dropped out and the producers tried various substitutes, whose failure Merton watched with undisguised glee. I said I thought Eddie Izzard was good but Merton corrected me - 'Not bad. His first one was good, second not bad - third one was awful. I'm not being unfair to him, but he was doing the same gags in the third week that he'd done in the second week. But I knew that nobody coming in could immediately pick up and do what I was doing, so I wasn't worried. And I thought me not doing a series would be a good shot in the arm - and it was. I think they missed me a lot, and since then I think we're in the best form we've ever been.'

But why is he often so rude to his guests - why does he ignore them so cruelly? He says first, they're not his guests, he has no say in choosing them, he's not even allowed to go into the Have I Got News production office because they say he might see the questions. He only once managed to get his choice of guest on the programme - Spike Milligan - but other times when he's suggested someone he's been overruled. Nor does he have any power of veto - 'I mean, I've sat next to the Hamiltons and I'm no big fan of theirs.' But anyway he says he's not deliberately rude to the guests, or only once, to Teddy Taylor. But he concedes that he might sometimes appear rude. He recently played an old video of Peter Cook on the show and was shocked to see that he never spoke to Cook - 'It looks like I'm being spectacularly rude to him but it's just that, you know, I wanted to kiss him!'

He could make a perfectly good living from doing programmes like Have I Got News and Room 101 and Just a Minute (on Radio 4), where he just has to turn up and be funny. Turning up and being funny is no problem for him - he has been doing it since school, he still does it every Sunday at the Comedy Store, where he and Josie Lawrence and friends do a regular improv night, which he says is 'like flying - like jazz, almost'. He is amazed when people say that his Have I Got News jokes must be scripted - 'Nobody's ever given me a joke, I don't need it' - the only preparation he and Hislop get is that they see the headlines and pictures at the run-through half an hour beforehand.

But he gets a bit twitchy when people say he is so great on Have I Got News because 'It's just me being a panellist, and I don't think I'm really working at the top of my powers - I just sit there and say something rude about Michael Heseltine and everybody's pleased! It's not quite enough, really. I mean, it's wonderful to be doing a show that's so well paid, and all I have to do is turn up on the Thursday at half five and by 9 o'clock I'm done. And 16 weeks of the year that's all I do and for someone who worked in the civil service, who used to dread going into work on a Monday... So I enjoy Have I Got News and I'm glad people like it, but it's not all I want to do. It's not like making a great film or creating something that has longevity. And that's how I judge comedy, really - will it be funny in 40 years' time?'

So now he has made his pitch for longevity - written and directed a short film called The Suicidal Dog which is going out on arthouse release with Chuck and Buck over the next few weeks, and then being shown on BBC2 some time next year. I went to its premiere at the Raindance Festival the other week and it was well received, with plenty of laughs and big applause at the end. The big excitement for film buffs - and for Paul Merton - is that the director of photography is 86-year-old Jack Cardiff, who worked with Powell and Pressburger, with Hitchcock, with Houston (on The African Queen) and photographed Marilyn Monroe in The Prince and the Showgirl.

Merton only got him by accident because when Hat Trick, the producers, asked who he wanted as director of photography, he couldn't think of any names apart from Jack Cardiff, whose autobiography he'd read. Luckily Cardiff was a fan of Have I Got News and agreed to do it. But Merton was nervous the first day shooting because 'The crew all knew Jack or knew his reputation and were very very pleased to be working with him, whereas I'm just the bloke off the telly. So for the first few hours they were a bit unsure. And then I contradicted one of Jack's suggestions and there was a sort of hushed moment, everyone waiting to see what would happen, but then he said, "Yes, that's better, we'll do that." He could pull all kinds of rank on you, but he doesn't - he's a great man to work with and I was very lucky to get him.'

Also, Merton thinks, he's made a bit of film history, or at least film trivia. Jack Cardiff was a child actor before he was a cameraman and first appeared in a film aged four. He also appears (just the back of his head, on a train) in Merton's film - 'So that's 82 years between first and last film appearances - who else has had that much longevity? Not Lillian Gish, I don't think. Or Bette Davis. I'd have to look it up, but I think he's got to have some sort of record there.' This is exactly the sort of useless information Merton loves - for someone who only got grade five CSE in maths, he is weirdly hooked on numbers and statistics.

His big ambition now is to make more films - hopefully a full-length feature eventually. 'It's like a bug that bites you and gets in your bloodstream. There's something magical about film, it's the ultimate for me, because it's kind of permanent - inasmuch as anything is. When I went to see Buster Keaton when I was about 14 and I came out of the cinema having really laughed at this film which had been made 50 years before, I thought: That's immortality. It's fantastic. And if my film is shown after I'm gone and it gets laughs - it doesn't get any better than that, I don't think. Though obviously I'd prefer to live forever!'

 The Suicidal Dog is released on 10 November

You can't put a price on happiness,of course, but, according to the NatWest pensions index, you can give a figure for what it takes to be financially content in retirement.

On average, pensioners questioned for the NatWest survey said that they found life easy with a yearly before-tax income of £10,000 - although retired members of the professional classes said they needed an average of £15,000 to feel comfortably off.

The good news for future pensioners is that, since starting the survey in 1998, NatWest has found that the proportion of people on track for financial contentment has gone up from a fifth to a quarter of current workers.

And the bad news?

Three out of four people are heading for a financially difficult retirement because they are not paying enough into their pensions.

How much is enough?

Whatever it takes to achieve your desired retirement income. If you are in an occupational pension scheme, your employers should be able to tell you whether the amount you pay is sufficient or whether you need to top it up by making additional voluntary contributions (AVCs).

I've got a personal pension.

In that case, enough means the amount it will take to build up a sufficiently large fund to buy the level of income you think you will need to live on in retirement.

Can you be more specific?

When do you want to retire?

When I'm 60 in 20 years' time.

And how much income do you think you will you need?

Without taking a drastic cut in income, not much less than my current salary of £30,000.

Are you sure about that? How much do you currently spend on your mortgage and pension?

Including mortgage protection insurance, we spend about £600 a month on the mortgage and I pay £200 into my pension. I'm not sure what my wife pays.

And will you still need income to pay for those things once you're retired?

No. The mortgage will be paid off by then and I was rather hoping that the pension would start paying me.

In that case, would you agree that you could do without £9,600 of income a year?

I suppose so - and presumably I wouldn't need the £200 a month I pay in National Insurance either.

True. So a target pension of £18,000 would be quite reasonable?

Yes, but that still doesn't tell me whether I'm paying enough into my pension.

What is your personal pension currently worth?

About £30,000.

You're not paying enough.

What makes you so sure?

If you retired at age 60 today, you would need a fund of about £215,000 to buy an annuity which would pay you a pension of £18,000.

In 20 years' time - assuming that you want your target pension to keep pace with inflation at 3 per cent a year - you'll need a fund of about £390,000 to produce the same level of retirement spending power.

That's assuming that annuity rates remain the same, which is unlikely given that they have been falling in recent years.

Have you taken growth in my current fund and monthly contributions of £200 into account?

Yes, and basic-rate tax relief too. And even taking a supremely optimistic view - which is to assume that your fund will grow by 9 per cent a year - your fund would still be worth about £50,000 less than it needs to be. If the fund grew at 5 per cent a year, you would have less than half the amount you will need to buy a pension of £32,500.

Where did that figure come from?

It's £18,000 inflated at 3 per cent a year. If you want to check it, punch 18,000 into your calculator and keep multiplying by 1.03 until you've done it 20 times. Alternatively, multiply 18,000 by 1.03 to the power 20.

I see. So how much extra will I have to contribute to be sure that inflation doesn't erode the value of my pension before I've even started spending it?

If you want a precise figure which takes charges into account, ask your pension company. But make sure you ask them for an illustration for the 20-years hence pension figure rather than your target income in today's money.

Don't they do that automatically?

No. Only figures for 'protected-rights' pensions, which are those funded by contracting out of Serps (the state earnings-related pension) have to be given in real terms.

What if I can't afford to pay any extra?

You can forget early retirement.

Control, freedom and choice are advantages that self-invested personal pensions, or Sipps, seem to have over other personal pensions. So why were there only 50,000 Sipps among the 6 million private pensions taken out last year, and will this change as online Sipps arrive?

Sipps were introduced in 1989 to enable pension holders to manage their own investments. They can be used to build up a pension for retirement or, more traditionally, to house a fund set up after retirement.

Sipps, like other personal pensions, are available to employees who are not in company schemes, to the self-employed and to partnerships.

Thomas McPhail, pensions development manager for Wolverhampton-based financial adviser Torquil Clark says: 'Sipps would suit someone in their forties or fifties who wants to do something imaginative with their fund, and growth is tax free because it is in a pension fund. But you should have investment knowledge, or pay an adviser.'

The choice of investments under Sipps is wide. Money can go directly into shares or collective investments such as unit trusts as well as into life insurance and commercial property.

This means you don't have to place all your hard-earned cash with one provider, as you do with other personal pensions. You can diversify your investments to minimise risk, and take your pick of the best performers'z.

Nick Bamford, managing director of Cranleigh-based financial adviser Informed Choice, which does a lot of Sipps business, says: 'Sipps give you control over your investment, something many people find appealing given current disillusionment with providers.'

But they are perceived as expensive. There are set up charges, annual charges, fund management charges and trading charges - all of which can run into thousands of pounds, making small Sipps impractical.

McPhail says: 'They are definitely for high net worth clients. You are looking at making monthly payments of £400 to £500 a month on top of a lump sum transfer value or one off payment of £20,000.'

He says if the Sipp is for an income drawdown plan - which allows you to keep your fund invested in the stock market after retirement while you draw an annual income from it - you need£100,000.

But if you are seeking a spread of investments, you could consider a personal pension such as Skandia's which invests in a wide range of funds without the hassle of all the trading involved with Sipps.

Bamford disagrees.'If you are using a Sipp for income drawdown, you will have to build up a substantial fund, he says. 'But the situation is different if you are building up a fund. It works out cheaper than taking out a pension through an insurance company.'

Sipp charges do vary. Establishing a Sipp can cost anywhere between £500 and £1,000, while management fees can be as much as £500 a year. The trading fee is typically 1 per cent of the deal.

Life insurer National Mutual's Sipp has a setting-up charge of £625 and an annual management fee of £400. If you trade yourself, it will cost you £25 a shot. James Hay's Sipp has a setting-up fee of £290 and an annual management charge of £455. Trading costs a minimum of £30 each time.

However, it is launching a new Sipp through financial advisers on 1 November. Its Select Sipp rolls all the fees into an annual charge of 0.75 per cent. This translates into £750 on a £100,000 fund, plus commission agreed with the adviser.

A new operation has stripped out all these costs by selling Sipps online. Sippdeal.co.uk is offering a Sipp whose only charge is the trading fee - between £15 and £30, depending on the size of the deal. It hopes to bring Sipps to a much wider audience.

The minimum contribution is £150 a month on top of a lump sum investment of £1,000. It is aimed at people who trade online.

At present it is only possible to invest in shares through Sippdeal - 'though by early next year we will be offering a full range of unit trusts which will bypass this limitation,' says spokesman Fergus Lyons.

National Mutual wants to make Sipps the mainstay of its business, and predicts that 500,000 people will have them by 2010, after forthcoming changes to the income drawdown rules make the plans transferable.

Its head of Sipps marketing, Malcolm Gordon, says: 'Sipps are like buying madeto-measure clothes for the same price as off-the-peg ones. They offer good-quality investment services coupled with control, choice and the ability to negotiate on investments.'

Sipps may be for you if you want more say in how your fund is managed. If you haven't the money for a bespoke service, there is now the cheaper online option. But you do need good investment knowledge - or a willingness to pay for it.

The other day I was in a restaurant, eavesdropping on a couple having a leisurely, mid-week lunch. The woman's mobile phone rang. Her spoon was halfway to her mouth as she said: 'Yes, you can make tea and coffee in your room. Yes, they're all en-suite. Fifty pounds deposit usually, a cheque's fine'. After the call she said to her husband: 'I forgot to tell you, the hand basin in the pink room is blocked again'.

Running your own business - whether it's a hotel or anything else - may give you flexibility, but mention the word 'freedom' to many owners of these enterprises and they're likely to respond with a hollow laugh. Yet surely it must feel great, calling the shots? You can put your mark on something, make decisions, choose who you work with, and take a break without needing to get your holiday form signed by the powers that be.

When you are employed by someone else and your concentration lapses during the Monday morning meeting, you may find yourself dreaming again of that restaurant you'd really like to open, possibly in Devon, or maybe even in Cornwall? One day you'll do it. It would be a dream come true!

Yet there are dreamers and doers. Galvanising yourself to hand in your notice, to give up a job that pays the bills and comes with four weeks' paid holiday is not for the fainthearted.

Nevertheless, according to a recent NatWest survey, 440,000 new businesses were set up in 1999, the highest number for 10 years. Does that mean that the entrepreneurial spirit is on the up? Indeed, if the stereotypical Open All Hours culture of a small business owner may have previously put off the steady nine to fivers, in a world where working hours have been stretched beyond all recognition and with organisations in constant flux, perhaps more of the employed brigade are wondering whether they should give it a whirl?

'It may be sensible to make sure you're in control of your destiny, rather than being in the hands of a multinational,' says David Boyle of the New Economics Foundation, a think-tank.

Some people try their luck, but then have second thoughts, according to Andrew McDougall of Barclays Small Business Banking. 'People start out in a business venture, but then they might get a better offer of employment,' he says.

Which may console the many people who are still toying with the idea of being mavericks, yet remain fearful about the financial precariousness associated with running a business: wages to pay and the ever-present threat of mounting debts and bankruptcy.

'People have fear, and one of the things we put our fear on is money,' says Nick Williams, a former Eighties yuppie who gave up a highly paid job in computers to advise people how to find their ideal employment. 'Yet fear and money are different.'

Williams, author of The Work You Were Born To Do , published by Element Books at £9.99, says our belief in the work ethic can shackle us further if we run our own businesses: 'One of our beliefs is that we can only earn money through hard work, effort and struggle so we may make ourselves work harder when we are self-employed. You can end up being your own worst boss.'

Yet self-employment is something that more and more of us are turning to as freelance and portfolio working becomes a more flexible and profitable option. Does that mean that anyone with a laptop can claim to run a small business?

'For me, a business is something that has an intention to grow,' says Andrew James, publisher of Better Business magazine. 'Any business that is going to grow probably doubles in size by the end of the first year. And the only way that you can grow a business is by delegating.'

James says it's important to recognise the difference between a business and a job: 'There are a number of people who start a business. There are many more who buy a job for themselves: they don't really see themselves as running a business.'

So what makes people grasp the nettle? For some it's redundancy. For others it's a mid-life crisis - the 'there must be more to life' syndrome suffered after being in a job where one's creativity is stymied - can fuel a now-or-never attitude.

Other people have a spirit shot through with an entrepreneurial, inventive streak. They have an idea and they want to make it work. Think Diane Keaton in Baby Boom.

Whatever the initial motivation, you'll need energy, determination, a Zen-like philosophical outlook and passion. And wave farewell to holidays, at least for the first few years.

Where to get help

Better Business publishes newsletters and runs a website with useful links, help and advice for self-employed people and small business owners.

Nick Williams at the Heart at Work project runs courses that examine our relationship with money. The next workshop - on abundance - is at the Commonwealth Institute, London, on 25 November: tel 07000 781 922.

Business Link has regional offices and offers advice and runs courses for people wanting to start businesses.
