Jason Biggs became a youth icon last year by demonstrating the proper manner of making love to pastry in the comedy hit American Pie. An odd path to international stardom, maybe, but capitalising on his fame has not, so far, been easy. Biggs had the only good role in fizzless romantic comedy Boys and Girls (due for release in December), but even more vexing is Loser, written and directed by Clueless's Amy Heckerling and co-starring Pie-mate Mena Suvari. Loser stars Biggs as a nerdy university freshman who can't get anything in his life to work right. Unfortunately, little in the film did, either, Biggs' performance being a notable exception.

Most women seem to think you're just the cuddliest thing. How come you're so often cast as a guy who can't get a date?

I like to think that I have a sympathetic quality that the audience can root for, even while I'm playing an outcast. In order for American Pie to have worked, you had to have a character that, even while he is humping a pie, the audience still liked him; and in order for Loser to work, you have to have a guy who, even while he is the biggest outcast, is still likable.

More speciÞcs on Mena, please. This is the second film you've made together.

Mena is great and completely unchanged by all the success of American Beauty and everything, which was hitting right when we started shooting this. She was very humble about it, and we had such a great time, always kidding around and laughing. There were a lot of inside jokes. I believe that our chemistry on screen is great, and I think that's because our chemistry off screen is great.

For whatever reason, though, Loser did pretty lousy when it was released in the US last summer. Did that bother you?

It would be foolish of me to take full responsibility for the movie, but at the same time, I'm very proud of it. So however the movie did, and whether or not it will impact on me or not, who knows? The only thing that I can control in the end is my performance. That's the only pressure that I feel, not so much for the film to succeed, because I am my own worst critic.

You seem to be working non-stop. Are you compulsive that way, or have you had time off we don't know about?

No, I stopped, but... American Pie came out, and so I travelled around the globe to do publicity for it, and then I came back and I started work on Boys And Girls and Loser, which I did at the same time. I finished that at the end of last January and I had a break. So then it was like, "Alright, it's Jason time! I'm going to go snowboarding, and have fun!" Then on my Þrst trip snowboarding, I dislocated my shoulder really badly. So Jason time turned into recovery time; I spent three months in physical therapy and a month in a sling. Then I started my next two projects, Saving Silverman and Prozac Nation.

Let's go out on a cheery seasonal note, then. What was the best Halloween costume you've ever worn?

There were two. One was when I was a prostitute in the sixth grade. My mom helped me out with that one. She cut some tennis balls in half and got this crazy wig and, like, put on the lipstick and short skirt. I shouldn't say prostitute, that's kind of heavy, I was a girl; but if you saw me, you would think that I belonged in a brothel. And I was a baby in the fifth grade, the year before that. I had a big diaper with a big pin, and a big paciÞer.

Man, sounds like you really were a loser.

No, that was cool! It was fun because I didn't have to leave for bathroom breaks.

Can the red-eye be abolished forever? Can a night-flight be transformed from a punishing experiment in sleep deprivation into a travellers' treat, on a par with the old luxury night-trains of old?

British Airways certainly hopes so. That's why it's equipped its club-class quarters with a perk that used to be confined to first: a flat-bed seat. Think of it as the latest offensive in the great furniture war of the air - a bed in the sky for every business-class passenger between London and New York.

Personally, I couldn't resist. I've done that overnight run often, always in economy, emerging the next morning with aching limbs, matted hair, clingy trousers and a desperate need for slumber. Wouldn't it be great to dodge the entire experience by bedding down for the night at JFK and arriving in London fresh and ready for the new day?

BA's new service is obsessed with achieving that outcome. Sleep is the goal, pursued relentlessly. There's pre-board dining in the newly-built Terraces lounge in JFK: that way you can eat first, wasting no valuable sleep time onboard. If you're one of those travellers who skids into the airport with seconds to spare - and no time for the lounge - then the on-board menu includes a sleep-well option (olive bread stuffed with beef and ricotta cheese, followed by hot chocolate and cookies). It's not so much food as a soporific.

But the heart of the matter is the seat. It looks less like a chair than a pod. There are two seats in each unit, forming an S-shape - with a handy, fan-like screen to ensure no peeking between you and your neighbour (unless you want to). A TV screen swings out on a steel arm; there's a tiny little stand for cocktails as well as the regular tray table stowed in the seat arm. Also stashed away is a TV remote control, which doubles as a telephone, and a clutch of light-switches and gadgets. Once you've checked out all that lot - and the instruction manual is essential - you'll feel like Blofeld in a Bond movie. It's not a chair, it's a console.

If you find cramped legroom the true curse of economy travel, your heart will leap when you see the footstool folded away in front of you. Unlock it and a neat pumping action raises or lowers it to just the right height. Press the recline button and you'll think yourself blessed: comfy chair, feet up - the perfect conditions for watching a movie or reading a book.

But that's not the point. You must keep pressing the button and keep pressing some more. For the chair bends further and further back (forcing you to move your bottom, lest your backside gets trapped in the chair like a foot in an escalator). The electric movement takes the seat back to a full horizontal, until its front edge meets the footstool. Ta-da: it's a bed!

The frequent fliers are unfazed by all this, of course; these blasé habitues of business class know exactly what to do. They put away their Wall Street Journal before take-off, heading instead to the (larger than usual) bathroom where they swiftly change into sweatpants and cosy top (BA only provides the "sleepsuit" to first class). They don't eat on the plane, waving aside the offer of a menu, and they certainly don't drink. They don't bother unwrapping the headset or checking out the film guide.

Instead, they curl up under the blanket, buckle their belt over the top (so the steward can see it, and won't wake them during turbulence), and drop off in an instant. It seems high-powered folk are focused about everything they do - even sleep.

Within minutes, the cabin has the feel of a boarding-school dorm. The lights are dimmed, there are no announcements and all is quiet. And people are really asleep! Mouths are open, arms are dangling. No one snored on my flight but the business elite were definitely in the land of $500,000-a-year nod. (One cannot escape the suspicion that a few of them were getting a bit of chemical help: among the jetset, sleeping pills are the new coffee.)

I, alas, was not among them. My chair was comfortable, and it was long enough even for me (at 6 ft 1). But somehow I was denied full unconsciousness. Normally I would blame that on the plane and the tiny seat. Now I know the truth: the seat is perfect - it's me who has to change.

 A BA fully-flexible return ticket to New York costs £3,743. A Premium Leisure Saver in Business Class costs £3,375. Details: 0845 7733377.

Vienna is the grand capital of music. Hadyn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert all thrived in its bubbling coffee-house culture and came to pay court to the Habsburgs and to each other. Today along the Kartnerstrasse, Vienna's central shopping street, busy Viennese still hover patiently as buskers tune up. Even the mobile phones chime.

Now is a good time to ride Vienna's trams around the Ringstrasse, looping the old city. The opera season is starting and, with Christmas approaching, Vienna lights up like a sparkler.

But the home of so much pleasure is also the city of Freud and that artistic reject Hitler; a place that can still cast truly grotesque shadows. For an outsider Vienna can be over-rich to say the least and, on a weekend break, penetrating its charmed musical circle is as intimidating as the overmighty Hofburg palace. Fear not though, Vienna is actually remarkably easy to get around.

Tuning up

Buy a Vienna Card (£9 for three days - from underground stations and tobacconists) for unlimited use of trams, subway and discounts to most museums. For anyone vaguely nervous of all that noise, there is only one place to start. Just three months old, Vienna's newest, slickest, most hi-tech museum, the Haus der Musik, is a revelation. It starts with a computerised introduction to the sounds of music and music of sounds, and ends in a futuristic playground of sonic massages and sound morphing. You can even conduct the Vienna Philharmonic courtesy of a computer program masterminded by the university of Linz.

For a genuine insight into what made all those metronomes tick, the coupes de theatre are the walk-through biographies of Vienna's seven great composers, from "Papa" Hadyn to Mahler and the dissonance of the 20th-century Viennese School. They brilliantly weave their stories into the fabric of the city and show how music, beginning in the churches, moved to the court and aristocratic salons, then through Schubert's open-air gatherings to the all-popular waltzes of the Strausses, preparing the way, in the collapse of empire and two world wars, for the shattering atonalities of the 20th century. "When you hear a sound you are also hearing the space in which it is made." It couldn't be truer than in Vienna.

Haus Der Musik, Seilerstatte 30. (+4315164851 www.houseofmusic-vienna.at). Open 10am-10pm daily. Adults £5, family ticket £11.

Next stop the Hofburg palace and an exhibition of 16th-century musical instruments, not just to touch bass but as an introduction to the Habs burgs. The winter palace of the Holy Roman emperor Franz Joseph, who defined the staggering pomp and circumstance of the 19th- century city, the Hofburg lies at Vienna's epicentre. It symbolises how this capital of an empire, once uniting 56 million people in the heart of the European maelstrom, became such a glittering focus for art and culture.

The Hofburg could take a weekend in itself but a must on a short trip is the Hofburg Chapel where every Sunday morning you can hear the Vienna Boys Choir. Make sure to get a seat near the front, otherwise you will have to peer at those angelic faces on a monitor.

Instruments of the 16th Century - National Library in the Hofburg Palace, Innere Stadt. Open 10am-5.30am except Tuesday. £2.50.

If the Hofburg testifies to the importance of patrons, it is the composers who play on and, armed with enough anecdotes, Vienna's drama explodes in the places they frequented. I didn't know Beethoven was always running upstairs or that Mozart spent a third of his life in carriages.

Everywhere you'll see plaques to Vienna's musical worthies, but two of the most important pilgrimage sites are the Pasqualati House and The Figaro House . Beethoven - who moved house 97 times - found a burgherish patron in Herr Pasqualati. The charming Figaro House lies in cobbled streets behind the all-imposing St Stephen's, the only surviving residence of Vienna's best loved visitor, Wolfgang Amadeus. Under the baroque ceiling in his bedroom you do get a real sense of Mozart's (or perhaps Peter Schaffer's) Vienna. Headphones and digital harpsichords allow you to indulge in some of the greatest works in situ.

It was the commercially-minded Strausses who really began to exploit popular music with their celebrated waltzes. Although the Danube is not and never has been blue, as you will see from the tributary that now forms Vienna's famous canal, you will hear the strains of waltzes everywhere. Vienna's ball season starts again too in November, although it doesn't reach its peak until January and February.

PasqualatiHaus, Molkerbastei 8. FigaroHaus, Domgasse 5. Johann Strauss Memorial Rooms, Praterstrasse 54. All open 9am-12.15pm, 1pm-4.30pm Tues- Sun. Closed Jan 1, May 1 & Dec 25.

Nights at the opera

The two main concert halls are the Musikverein (1 Bösendorferstrasse 12, tel: 505 8190) and the Konzerthaus (3 Lothringerstrasse 3, tel: 712 1211), home of the Vienna Philharmonic and Symphony orchestras.

But the high altar of musical culture is the splendid Staatsoper (1 Opernring 2, tel: 5144 42960), completely rebuilt in 1945. Sometimes, the humourless Viennese could do with the Marx brothers around, but for me there was no greater thrill than watching those deep-red curtains rise on a production of Verdi's Enani, as well-dressed Viennese showed their love, knowledge and appreciation in one of the world's greatest opera houses. Of course, seats are expensive but you can stand for around £5 - if you can get tickets.

Try, too, the Volksoper (9 Währingerstrasse 78, tel: 51 444) - the People's Opera. Far more relaxed, it still reaches a high standard and you are more likely to hear the strains of Figaro or Don Giovanni drifting through the doors.

For tickets to everything theatrical and musical, go to the Bundestheatrekassen (1 Hanuschgasse 3, down from the opera house, tel:5144 42960).

Tone deaf

If music isn't your thing, Vienna has plenty of other attractions. It is a city of theatres and museums, 90 in fact. A reason to go now is the exhibition in the Belvedere of Klimt's Women; a banquet of the painter's rich, jewelled colours, and decadent sensuality. To escape take a boat along the canal and loop out into the Danube.

Klimt's Women, Belvedere, Landstrasse. Until Jan 7. Open 10am-6pm except Mondays. Thurs to 7pm. £5. www.klimt-frauen.at.

In Vienna, even the horses love to dance and though it's difficult to get tickets you can watch them training in the mornings at the Spanish Riding School (Hofburg, Josefplatz).

Fiakers, Vienna's famous horse-drawn carriages, are very expensive and far better value is a personal guided tour.

For some darker notes, try the Prater Park and the sounds of the funfair. From the famous Ferris wheel where Harry Lime spills the beans in The Third Man you can gaze out across the city, over to the UN building, housing among other things the Drug Control Agency. For film buffs there is also a guided tour down to the sewers, called The Return of The Third Man (tel: 585 6455).

Where to eat

Vienna is almost as famous for food as music. The Sacher Hotel (1 Philharmonikerstrasse 4, behind the Opera House, tel: 514 560) invented the sachertorte (chocolate cake) for Prince Metternich, and everywhere windows groan with pastries, puddings and sweets. This is all most pleasurable in the city's numerous coffee houses.

Several boast musical associations but my favourites are the pink-fronted Café Diglas (1, Wollzeile 10, tel: 512 8401), and Hawelka (1 Dorotheerhasse 6, tel: 512 8230), still frequented by artists and musicians.

The tourist board has an excellent booklet of concert-cafés.

Café Landtmann (1 Dr-Karl-Lueger-Ring 4, tel: 532 0621) was a favourite of Freud's and is great for music.

You shouldn't leave Vienna without trying tafelspitz , a delicious Viennese beef stew, best at Plachutta (1 Wollzeile 38, tel: 512 1577). For lunch, Hansen (1 Wipplingerstrasse 34 in the basement of the Stock Exchange, tel: 532 0542) is trendy, the Cantino (at the top of the Haus der Musik) good, while Zum Zwarzen Kameel (1 Bognergasse 5, tel: 533 8967) is famous for its reislings and a still-unpaid bill of Beethoven's.

If you are going to the opera, be careful because Vienna seems to close suprisingly early. However, there is a good restaurant right opposite the Volksoper and several places to eat next to the Staatsoper. Corso (1 Hotel Bristol, Mahlerstrasse 2, tel: 5151 6546) is wonderful if you are really pushing the boat out, but for an after-opera meal go next door. Drei Husaren (1 Weihburggasse 4, tel: 5121 0920) is another famous upmarket restaurant, while Barbaro's (1 Kärtner Strasse 19, tel: 513 1712) at the top of a modern department store is not expensive and has great views. A traditional pre-opera tipple is a glass of champagne at the Reiss Bar ( Marco D'aviano-Gasse 1).

For some real life and the street culture that fed all that genius, try the student bars around Juden Strasse.

Where to stay

As everything happens in the charmed inner circle, district number 1 is the only place to stay. Our hotel the Romischer-Kaiser (1 Rathausstrasse 17, just next to the Haus Der Musik, tel: 512 7751) is both comfortable and elegant.

Another delightful though expensive hotel is König Von Ungarn - The King of Hungary (1 Schulerstrasse 10, tel: 515 84, doubles around £120). With a lovely inner courtyard it is next to Mozart's house and the Café Diglas just round the corner.

For somewhere cheaper, try Drei Kronen (Schleifmühlgasse 25, tel: 710 1919, doubles £44 per night) in the unmissable Naschmarkt, Vienna's most exciting market.

 David Clement-Davies' novel Fire Bringer is published in paperback by Macmillan at £5.99.

The practicals

Inghams Eurobreak (020-8780 7700, www.inghams.co.uk) offers two nights at the four-star Hotel Romischer Kaiser for £172 per person including Buzz return flights from Stansted and a free Dorling Kindersley guidebook worth £14.99. Tickets for the Volksoper (£14-£61) and Staatsoper (£17-£165) and the half-day city tour (£22pp) can be booked in advance through Inghams.

In the brochure the chalet looked idyllic. It was framed by thick lusty pine trees topped with generous dollops of snow. Inside a log fire blazed. It was a short walk from the slopes, where a small gondola took you to the main ski station at Courchevel 1850.

Unlike the functional but unattractive hub of the Trois Vallées, we were staying in Courchevel 1550 - one of the five components of the resort that link to the 600km of pistes. Down the mountain from the jet-setting Courchevel 1850, we were in a small, quiet and attractive village, ideal for families and substantially cheaper.

A short gondola ride or alternatively a regular bus service were all that separated the two areas - that is until it started to snow, and snow and snow. Later that night we watched the snow build on the balcony, and as the flakes grew to the size of a fist and the wind started to howl our first concerns set in.

The next morning all was quiet, there was no hum from the gondola, our essential link to the main ski area, and the buses had stopped running. Eventually, a short Poma lift was opened, but it didn't go anywhere, all it did was justify the price of a lift ticket. We were well and truly cut off.

In New York City, any real estate agent will tell you that the three most important factors to take into account when looking for accommodation are location, location, location. The same could well apply to ski resorts. Sadly though, the most attractive resorts may not have the best skiing or reliable public transport, while the most convenient may not be attractive. In many cases it comes down to what you are prepared to pay.

Many of the purpose-built resorts are popular because they offer location and convenience at affordable prices. This doesn't mean that you should forego the pretty villages where the smell of manure wafts through the narrow cobbled streets and 400-year-old chalets groan from the passing of time, but that you should choose your alpine hideaway with care.

In Austria, where many traditional alpine villages have barely changed and hotels have been modernised or expanded in good taste, there are many resorts that combine convenience, and an attractive village, and a few that can add excellent skiing to the list.

In Switzerland, beware the antiquated four-star hotel. Last year, I went to Villars for the first time and found it a delightful location, with excellent skiing. But the so called four-star hotels, while meeting international standards, were tired and badly in need of renovation.

Italian resorts such as Courmayeur and Cortina D'Ampezzo have it all, but there are many other attractive Italian centres such as Livigno and Gressoney where you can find charm and good, albeit mostly, intermediate skiing. In France you'll find the purpose-built resort as the gateway to many of the largest ski areas.

Pretty Alpbach, Austria

The classic chocolate-box village with old wooden chalets, a small attractive church, narrow streets, and two 16th-century hotels run by the same family for several generations. The skiing is mostly intermediate on the Wiedersbergerhorn reached by a free shuttle bus. It's typically Tyrolean - expect cream teas, lederhosen and accordion players rather than tequila slammers and hip-hop.

Who goes there:

Crystal Holidays 0870 848 7000
Inghams 020-8780 4444
Made to Measure 01243 533333
Megève, France

An exclusive and chic resort that attracted the likes of Brigitte Bardot, Roger Vadim and other celebrities in the 1960s. As the years passed, it kept its exclusivity intact as others seeking adventure continued on to Chamonix half an hour away. Now its much improved skiing, high standard of restaurants and luxury and unspoilt medieval village centre makes it very attractive indeed, although it is not cheap.

Who goes there:

Powder Byrne 020-8246 5300
Elegant Resorts 01244 897333
Thomson 0870 606 1470
Cortina d'Ampezzo Italy

Set in the Ampezzo valley and surrounded by the dazzling beauty of the Dolomites, Cortina is one of Europe's most attractive resorts. The traffic-free centre makes it easy to walk around a town with beautiful old frescoed buildings, lively shopping and excellent restaurants. The skiing is varied but best for intermediates and beginners.

White Roc 020-7792 1188

Momentum Travel 020-7371 9111
Wengen, Switzerland

As the train winds its way up from Interlaken to Wengen, the majestic setting of the Jungfrau region and the fabled Eiger is spectacular. I first went to Wengen when I was five and subsequently joined the Coggins, the kids classes of the Downhill Only Club begun by the British in 1925. We used to toboggan down the main road but no one seemed to mind. Many years on, it hasn't changed. There are still no cars, the skiing is superb and you can get the best hot chocolate and cream teas in the Alps.

Plus Travel 020-7734 0383
Neilson 0990 141414
Grimentz, Switzerland

Situated in the lovely Val d'Anniviers, not far from Crans Montana, Grimentz is a small, uncrowded, rustic village with no large buildings and a town centre where the ancient chalets on either side of a narrow cobbled stone path practically touch. It shares a ski pass with a few other small resorts that between them have varied and attractive skiing. Each month, there is a cheese- fondue evening and the opportunity to ski from the highest part of the resort to Grimentz under the light of the full moon.

Who goes there:

As yet no tour operators although Switzerland Tourism can arrange holidays 00800 100 200 30

Crested Butte, Colorado

Slip into the days of the Wild West as you drive down Main Street, where old buildings have been restored and have brightly painted wooden fronts that look like the set of a western. At night, the town centre looks like a fairyland but is still quintessentially American, with cold beer, good service, and cheery waitresses. The skiing, a couple of miles away is either intermediate or extreme. It has a cache of deeply challenging slopes in its Extreme Limits attracting the US's best.

Who goes there:

Ski the American Dream 020-8552 1201
Ski Equipe 0870 444 5533
Ugly La Plagne

La Plagne has one of the largest integrated ski areas in the Alps and is made up of 10 separate villages between 1,800m-2,100m, of which six are purpose-built. Those built in the 1960s are the ugliest, such as Aime La Plagne and Plagne Centre. Those built later - at Plagne 1800, Plagne Villages and Plagne Soleil - are less forbidding. The most popular is Belle Plagne which has an attractive town centre. These centres or satellites do represent some of the best ski-in ski-out convenience, which for families is a major selling point. One way to get away from the architectural eyesore is to find a secluded chalet.

Flaine, France

Flaine is a 1960s example of Bauhaus architecture. Its massive concrete buildings, designed to mirror the shadow and light of their surroundings, are enough to make any prospective skiers' heart sink. The skiing is excellent and varied with an abundance of snow that quickly compensates for the surrounding architecture.

Who goes there:

Tignes, France

Anyone who chooses to base themselves at Tignes, among arguably the worst architecture in the Alps, is there for one reason, the skiing. Tignes is not a good family resort and the public transport is frequent but crowded, but it's one of the best locations for ski-in ski-out accommodation and the skiing is sensational. No matter what conditions are like, there is always the Grande Motte glacier which is open all year and together with Val d'Isère it's the easiest access to the 300km of pistes. It's also popular with snowboarders.

Arriving by train, as you have to in this carless village with the Matterhorn in the background, takes some beating. Small battery-operated taxis take you to your hotel, often down a warren of streets where wooden cow sheds battle for space inbetween restaurants and chalets. The variety of skiing and the number of cosy mountain restaurants is unlimited. For a good cappuccino (not that you can't get it in Zermatt), ski over the Italian border to Cervinia.

St Anton, Austria

In the heart of the Arlberg region surrounded by magical mountain scenery and small villages easily reached on skis for lunch, St Anton can provide whatever you require. It has opulent top hotels, modest accommodation, nightlife for those with stamina, romance for newlyweds, sophistication for an older crowd. The off-piste skiing is limitless but you can take a piste circuit to St Christoph, Stuben and Lech, or you can drop off the back of the Valluga (accompanied by a guide) and head into Zurs.

Val lacks the cosy charm of small romantic destinations such as Alpbach, but much of the heart of town has been thoughtfully renovated, with the facade of most buildings executed in the local stone. There are some heavenly luxury chalets, the nightlife is good and the skiing sublime. It kicks off the season in early December with the first World Cup men's downhill.

Lock up your daughters, sons, livestock and power tools, because the floodgates are open. After decades of holding back the tidal wave of sex and violence, Britain is now undergoing a veritable frenzy of liberalisation.

Once we took pride in our reputation as the repression capital of Europe, but virtually every film you were never allowed to see has suddenly emerged from hibernation. "Hardcore" porn videos can now be bought over the counter instead of over the Channel; historical scandalisers like The Story Of O, Salo and In the Realm of the Senses are all enjoying a renaissance.

Former gore shockers like Texas Chainsaw Massacre are now material for primetime rather than municipal incinerators. Graphic sex is writhing its way onto the big screen, and the small screen too, as FilmFour prepares to broadcast Catherine Breillat's highbrow sexathon Romance in November.

Not that any of this should necessarily be reason to rejoice. For one thing, these liberties have had to be wrested from the hands of the moral minority, and for another, not all of these films were necessarily worth banning, or watching, in the first place.

Ever since Jack The Ripper caught sight of an exposed table leg and was impelled to embark on a Victorian killing spree, the link between provocative images and real-world side effects has taken a powerful hold in this country. Our moral custodians have unerringly erred on the side of caution, seizing anything remotely perturbing with a vigilance bordering on the fanatical, and justifying their actions legally with grey terms like "corrupt" and "deprave".

So what's changed? About four years ago, police informed the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) that material being released as R18 (ie hardcore porn) was actually too tame to merit the description, and therefore misleading. New guidelines were half implemented, but then Jack Straw entered the Home Office and effectively reversed the process.

A ping-pong match of appeals, refusals and judicial reviews ensued, and to everyone's surprise, the courts ruled that watching sex on TV really didn't harm many people (repetitive strain injury aside). "We don't sit in our ivory tower and say what people should watch," says Sue Clark of the BBFC, which recently undertook an extensive public survey. "We still have some of the strictest censorship rules in the world, but now we effectively accept that adults should be allowed to decide what they want to watch."

So here we are, officially relaxed and eager to watch anything we once couldn't. As any record producer knows, an official ban is the best publicity one could hope for, which explains why any film with a vague whiff of scandal attached to it is now being sprung from the vaults.

To put the record straight, though, the BBFC does not "ban" films. It classifies them, or doesn't as the case may be, and local authorities decide whether or not to screen them. This was the case with "cult erotic dramas" like The Story Of O, a kinky confection of Ferrero Rocher styling and consensual sado-masochism that caused a stir in 1975 and finally received a UK release this year.

Director Just Jaeckin, who also directed the equally notorious Emmanuelle (which received a certificate, with cuts), has fond but vague memories of the film: "For me, it was a beautiful story about love. It was not corrupting or pornographic, it was a fantasy, like Alice In Wonderland. But erotic, of course."

While it's unlikely The Story Of O or Emmanuelle could have corrupted anyone, it's also quite a stretch to imagine that they could have aroused anyone either. Apart from crimes against interior design, the only real reason to suppress them was so that bands like Air could rip off their soundtracks undetected.

Jaeckin's films did, however, show others the way to get sex onto cinema screens: make your film foreign and try to have some kind of plot. "Arthouse" has always been a way of evading the censors' scissors. Nagisa Oshima's In The Realm Of The Senses was passed in 1991 (only a 15-year wait), and the old erect-penis taboo was later lifted for Lars Von Trier's The Idiots, and Leos Carax's Pola X.

Catherine Breillat's Romance, in many ways an updated Emmanuelle, has as many erections as an R18 film, but was passed for cinema release virtually uncut. Pasolini's Salo has fared less well. Despite impeccable arthouse credentials, its blend of perverted sex, sadistic violence and coprophilia went down as well as an excrement souffle with the authorities, despite the fact that its themes of repression, consumption and sexuality were serious-minded.

Currently up for reclassification, it was seized by police when shown uncut at a Soho cinema in 1977 - narrowly staving off a nationwide outbreak of faeces-eating.

The only films truly banned in the UK were the infamous "video nasties" of the 80s. In this instance, the Department of Public Prosecutions stepped in to staunch the Betamax bloodbath which the BBFC was powerless to stop, and prosecuted about 60 films, including future classics such as The Driller Killer, The Evil Dead and Andy Warhol's Flesh For Frankenstein (Texas Chainsaw Massacre was not on the list, although it had been refused a certificate since 1975).

The "but horror films are supposed to be scary" argument didn't wash; a racy title or a lurid cover was enough (like the relatively tame I Miss You Hugs And Kisses, unwisely tagged "for those who like their sex with a lot of violence").

In the sober light of the 21st century, the majority of these low-budget splatterdramas are more hilarious than disgusting - such as Forest Of Fear, in which hippies become zombies after the FBI sprays their weed with an experimental herbicide, or Night Of The Demon, in which a victim is disembowelled by bigfoot, then whipped with his own intestines in slow motion.

There are still many uncertified titles, some of which are unlikely to ever see the light of day, but others only remain "banned" because they are so bad nobody has bothered to re-submit them. Despite our new climate of acceptance, censorship is still full of contradictions.

We are legally allowed to have sex at 16, but must wait another two years to see it on a screen. We are allowed to buy R18 videos but not receive them by mail, or bring them from abroad. And what we consider 18-certificate material, our European counterparts regularly classify as 15 or even 12. European porn producers still tone down their films for the UK market.

Perhaps another side-effect of this liberation is the consequences for eroticism as opposed to pornography. With a rising background-smut count - thanks to increasingly sexualised advertising, television, magazines - pornography is scuttling up the hardcore ladder into bizarre, almost medical realms. If there's a relationship between what is forbidden and what is erotic, we're heading for an age of tedious sexual ubiquity, where everything is permitted and nothing is exciting.

Perhaps we're overcompensating for all those years of repression and in a few years, as has happened with violence in films, we'll reach saturation - and start campaigning for less sex on our screens.

Texas Chainsaw Massacre, 11.45pm, Sat, C4; In The Realm of the Senses is on limited release; Salo is showing at the ICA and NFT in London; The Story Of O is out on DVD and video on Monday

Reel shockers
Five Þlms the censors still don't want you to see

Cannibal Holocaust (Ruggero Deodato, 1979)
The gory effects were so realistic Deodato had to go to court to prove it was fake. The ban is due to a brutal rape-murder and real-life animal killings. Makers of The Blair Witch are probably pleased since they ripped off its "found footage" structure.

Snuff (Michael & Roberta Findlay, 1974)
Argentina-made Manson family-like horror that spawned the "oh my god, they're really killing someone!" urban legend. In reality it was a B-grade horror (Slaughter) with a film-set killing tacked on the end.

Straw Dogs (Sam Peckinpah, 1971)
Highly accomplished thriller with Dustin Hoffman declaring war on Cornwall. Overshadowed by its notorious depiction of Susan George being raped and enjoying it. The censors always had it in for Peckinpah anyway.

Nekromantik (Jorg Buttgereit, 1987)
Necrophilia is a definite no-no, kinky threesomes with a corpse are positively unacceptable. And as for killing and skinning a real live rabbit, Nekromantik 2 features a particularly revolting seal autopsy.

Boy Meets Girl (Ray Brady, 1994)
Low-budget torture-chamber sexual horror set in London - not as grisly as some. Recently given an 18 certificate but still too nasty for video.

The notice by the museum entrance said: "Iranians 500 tumans, Foreigners 5,000." Ali, my guide, interpreter and general fixer was asking the unshaven attendant in the kiosk for tickets.

"One Iranian and one foreigner."

The official looked puzzled. "Where's the foreigner?"

Ali pointed to me.

"Oh, I thought that was your Iranian grandfather."

I was wondering whether to be offended by the insult - surely I don't look ancient and decrepit enough to be the grandfather of an overweight 26-year-old - when the ticket-seller addressed me in such fast colloquial Persian that, though my command of the language is better than it has any right to be after 30 years of disuse, I couldn't quite catch his drift. Before I could stop myself, I had cupped my hand to my ear and, in the quavering, piping voice of an old, deaf and stupid grandfather, was asking: "What? What?"

"You ... are ... welcome ... Sir," the man said very slowly, loudly and patronisingly. "May ... you ... never ... be ... weary!" It's a common enough Persian greeting, but he seemed to me to say it more pointedly than necessary. I consoled myself with the thought that I had saved myself 4,500 tumans (about $25) . Over the next 10 days, as we toured the country in Ali's clapped-out Fiat, playing the Iranian grandfather was to save me a lot more money, as well as getting me into the kind of cheap lodging-house that wasn't willing to take foreigners. This was lucky, since I was visiting the country at a time of year when most decent hotels are full.

Having come to Iran to look at pre-Islamic sites for a book about the ancient Persian prophet Zoroaster, I particularly wanted to witness the Persian New Year celebrations, still strongly Zoroastrian in tone in spite of nearly 1,300 years of Islam. This is the most popular holiday of the Iranian year and the Lonely Planet Guide suggested that it was not the best time for a visit: "You should seriously consider avoiding Iran altogether for about 10 days before and after Noruz, the chaotic Iranian New Year, which starts on or about 21st March."

Ignoring this advice, my plan was to spend 10 days driving in a great circle around the country. Iran is a difficult country to travel in. Neither trains nor planes seem to serve the most sought-after destinations, and I had no idea of the condition of the roads. It was going to be touch and go whether I would make it back to Tehran in time for my return flight and my daughter's birthday back home.

The start was inauspicious. Daylight-saving time began the day I arrived, and I dutifully set my watch forward. The next morning we were to set off at six, but Ali was more than an hour late. He laughed when I pointed to the clock on the hotel lobby wall. "We don't work for the government," he protested. "And the Mullahs don't control the sun."

Nor, it seems, the roads. After two hours' playing dodgem through Tehran's insane morning traffic I was genuinely relieved to find myself still alive. No self-respecting Iranian driver will forego overtaking just because another vehicle is coming the other way. Two lanes are expected to accommodate three cars, or even trucks, abreast, even if it means scraping through, hooting like mad, with only inches to spare on either side.

Starting out, you can't help holding your breath and gripping the seat, white knuckled, at the hairiest moments. But there is a limit to the number of times you can brace yourself for certain death. In the end you learn to say, with the Iranians, Masha'allah: whatever God wills.

Our first, 500-mile drive south through the rolling desert took us to the oasis city of Yazd, with its unique skyline of tall wind towers, designed to catch any faint breaths of breeze and funnel them down into secret retreats at the heart of the huddle of mud-brick houses. We spent the next day visiting Yazd's spectacular mosques, its prison attributed to Alexander the Great and its Zoroastrian fire-temple, packed during Noruz with Iranian tourists craning to catch a sight, through the protective glass, of the sacred fire which has been burning continuously since AD 470, though not in this same place.

A few years ago after a great windstorm, Yazdis were amazed to see the top of a dome peek out of the sand just outside town. Much digging exposed an entire buried village, perfectly preserved, complete with a fire-temple of its own. During our visit, a local family party arrived. The father, who seemed to have insider knowledge, was lecturing his wife and daughter about Zoroastrian beliefs in the wildly theatrical style Iranians use when reciting verse - drawling out the long vowels as if eating them, peppering each sentence with sudden loud phrases or unexpectedly ... slowing ... right ... down. I whispered to Ali that this must surely be a schoolteacher by trade. The man heard me and turned on us.

"Were you speaking English?"

Ali confessed. The man pointed at me.

"Is he British? Because there are some things that should not be spoken in front of some people."

"Well," Ali told him, "he carries a British passport, but his family came from Czechoslovakia and he himself was born in Vienna."

The schoolteacher looked at me a little more benignly. "Then his sins are diminished."

Afterwards I said to Ali "I thought it was the Americans who were the Great Satan."

"Oh no," he explained, "Iranians believe that the Americans are good people at heart but innocent and naïve. It is always the British who command them to do bad things."

The first threat to our tight schedule came on my third Iranian night. All hotels in Yazd being full, we were sleeping on the living room floor of a local man's basement flat. Generously hospitable like all Iranians, he brought out a hookah and a brace of bottles of wine for his guests.

"Alcohol? Isn't that against the law?"

"I don't drink it for enjoyment, only for health," he emphasised, as if that made all the difference. "Anyway, it's not made from grapes, but from pomegranates and honey." The first taste confirmed that nobody could drink it for enjoyment.

The resulting hangovers delayed our next day's departure south over the mountains until noon, so that it was too dark to see anything by the time we reached Cyrus the Great's tomb at Pasagard and the spectacular remains of Persepolis, the summer capital founded by Darius and burned by Alexander. My executive decision was to press on to Shiraz and return again very early the next morning.

Even at 10 o'clock, Shiraz, elegant city of palaces, poets and perfumed gardens, was like a madhouse. All of Iran seemed to have congregated there for Noruz. Festive crowds pressed along the decorated streets, while gaily-dressed wedding parties, the women's black chadors barely concealing their finery, crammed on to the backs of lorries and paraded through the city centre, shouting and hooting and blaring raucous wind instruments.

After two hours of fruitless driving around to find a vacant hotel room, Ali regretfully conceded that we would have to make do with a common lodging house. He found the Heavenly Guesthouse near the central glittering Sayyed Mir Ahmad shrine but came out looking gloomy.

"You won't like it," he said.

I didn't. The tiny room, with space only for a double bed and a washbasin, was so filthy that Ali suggested we avoid undressing. The smell of urine forced us to leave the window open, and rowdy wedding parades outside kept us awake till three. It was no hardship to be up again and ready to leave town at five.

Lost time was impossible to make up, however. Though we were back shortly after seven at Cyrus's movingly simple and dignified tomb, the entrance gates to the site were locked and, in spite of my offer of money and Ali's improbable claims of high political influence, a dishevelled and bad-tempered official refused us admission for nearly two hours.

Late that night, we were 200 miles behind schedule when exhaustion forced us to stop in a small town on the road, at a guest house which proved to be, if anything, even more awful than the one in Shiraz.

In the morning I asked Ali the name of the place. "I want to be sure never to come here again."

"Beh-behan," he said. "Literally, it means 'Used-to-be-better'."

Driving on that night into the hours of darkness turned our careering descent to the oilfields of Mesopotamia into an awesome light show. Gigantic gas flares sprang from the ground on all sides, painting the entire sky a flickering rose red, as if we were entering the gates of Hell. It was almost a surprise to arrive unscathed in the cool modern urbanity of the great oil town of Ahwaz.

Next day, it was an even greater surprise to be thoroughly frisked on leaving the slick shopping mall by the banks of the Karun river, though Ali took the indignity for granted. "Otherwise people would steal things," he said.

But even Ali was taken aback when the best hotel in town refused to change my dollars at a respectable rate, on the grounds that some of them were more than a year old. The cashier claimed to be worried. "Perhaps they are not valid any more."

I suggested that the day that two-year-old dollar bills went out of date, the world economy might as well close down. "Why?" he asked. "Here we change our money all the time."

By the time we had reached the nine o'clock position in our 360 degree circumnavigation of the country, we were falling ever more behind schedule. We had to press on far into the night to reach Shush, the site of Susa, one of oldest and longest-lasting of ancient Iran's cities - and one that took the brunt of the enemy onslaught during the Iran-Iraq war. The dusty hill of ruins which was once the biblical Shushan stands opposite the supposed tomb of the Prophet Daniel, the forecourt of which - for the benefit, I suppose, of Jewish pilgrims - is daubed with a huge savage mural, in uncannily Belfast-like style, showing heroic Muslims capturing Jerusalem. Close by is a gruesome blood-and-guts exhibition memorialising the martyrs to Saddam Hussein.

Leaving the ancient mound, I was so affected by this combination of ruthlessness and horror that I quite forgot my Iranian grandfather role - until three angry men came running up to stop us in the street. Too late, I realised that I had been speaking English.

"You didn't say you were with a foreigner when you bought tickets," their spokesman accused Ali aggressively.

"You didn't ask."

"Foreigners must pay 10,000 tumans."

Ali was squaring up for an argument. "There is no sign that says so."

The two others were beginning to look belligerent. I feared they might call the police and that I would never get back to Tehran in time to catch my plane.

"Pay them the money and let's go," I said.

Ali did, but with ill grace. "It's $57. You know the money will go straight into their pockets."

"But I don't want to miss my daughter's birthday."

By driving through the night, we somehow managed to visit the carved cliffsides near Kermanshah and the ancient city of Hamadan as planned, and still arrive back in Tehran on the right day. With huge relief I checked in at Mehrabad airport well on time.

The check-in clerk looked sombre. "I am sorry," he said. "Your flight is being diverted via Baku. You are going to miss your connection to London. The airline will pay for your overnight hotel in Dubai."

I protested, of course. But this time there was absolutely nothing I could do.

 In Search of Zarathustra, Paul Kriwaczek's look at the influence of the ancient Persian prophet on world religions, will be published by Weidenfeld & Nicolson in 2001.

Visa

You can apply for a tourist visa at the Iranian consulate in London (Kensington Court, London W8, tel: 020-7937 5225), for a non-returnable fee of £40. You may be asked for a sponsor in Iran. There are agencies on the internet, which offer to do it all for you-for a fee. Otherwise be prepared to queue.

Getting there

Iran Air (020-7409 0971) flies Heathrow to Tehran from £380 return. British Airways (0345 222111) flies Heathrow to Tehran from £559 return. Cox and Kings (020-7873 5000, www.coxandkings.co.uk) organises a 10-night Treasures of Persia tour for £1,495.

Health

It's definitely worth calling in at the BA travel health centre in Regent Street (London W1). For a reasonable fee, they will provide all necessary jabs as well as give you a computer printout detailing the latest health news and Foreign Office travel advice.

Money

Surprisingly, the foreign currency most generally accepted is the US dollar. Mastercard is the preferred plastic. There is a difference between the official exchange rate and that on the street, but changing money unofficially is illegal, risky and not recommended. Banks will do the exchange, but hotels usually give a quicker, easier far less bureaucratic service. The current rate is around 1750 Iranian rials to the dollar, though Iranians themselves calculate in tumans (10 rials).

Accommodation

Cost varies wildly between about $120 a night at the top end of the scale down to $25 near the bottom. You wouldn't want to stay in a cheaper place.

Food

Earlier this year, the former Intercontinental Hotel in Tehran, now called the Laleh, was charging $30 for breakfast. On the other hand, you can get a filling meal in a roadside kebab house for under $5. No wine or beer, of course - except for a really horrid local non-alcoholic brew. Non-Muslim foreigners may be allowed to bring a small amount of alcohol into the country for their own use, but the hassle isn't worth it. Tea is the preferred drink in Iran and very good.

Travel

Buses are extremely cheap. The journey from Tehran in the north to Shiraz in the south, about 550 miles, costs around $2. A car with a driver will cost anything from $25 to $100 a day. But away from his home, you will have to pay for the driver's food and accommodation.

Overall cost

My 10 days in Iran cost $1,500 overall plus the air fare. It was definitely worth it.

Feasibility

Forget the TV images of chanting fanatics - that's merely political window-dressing. Iranians are friendly and welcoming, a highly civilised and cultured people with a longer and more distinguished history than almost any other nation - 2,500 years of it. The country is a treasure chest of magnificent architecture and fabulous antiquities. In spite of what one might expect from a theocracy, Iranian Islam is mostly tolerant and Iranian democracy has free and fair elections, though from a limited list. Under normal circumstances, a tourist visit is entirely feasible, even for a woman on her own.

Yesterday's third-quarter US GDP figures must come as a relief to the policymakers at the Federal Reserve. With a tight labour market and an annualised second-quarter figure of 5.6% the Fed was under pressure. Some argued its chairman Alan Greenspan was losing the touch that has elevated him to near legendary status. Others that he was allowing Opec to do the Fed's dirty work for it through an escalating oil price. Certainly, given the closeness of the presidential election, the Fed had little room for manoeuvre on interest rates.

In the event, yesterday's figure of 2.7% must have been as good as the Fed dared hope. It was undoubtedly a great deal better than Wall Street had been expecting. With the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq now well below their overvalued peaks and evidence that the economy is slowing Mr Greenspan might claim to be viewed as a man who kept his nerve rather than one who had lost the plot.

Well, maybe. One swallow does not make a summer, nor one set of GDP figures a soft landing. Even within yesterday's numbers there is cause for concern. It is business, rather than the consumer, which is spending less. That 2.7% would look more benign if the emphasis was the other way round. And while US share prices have pulled back from earlier scary heights, recent volatility shows they could yet deliver a destabilising shock.

So far, so good, then, Mr Greenspan. But there is still a long way to go - far enough indeed to make yesterday's talk of lower US interest rates look singularly premature.

Time to decide

It has been the most delicious of ironies - a hostile bid for a stock exchange. But now day 46 has come and gone and with it OM's last chance to raise its offer for the London Stock Exchange. All that remains is for shareholders to choose and for the votes to be counted. It is too early to be certain but at this stage it looks as if OM has shot its bolt.

Many in the City have been impressed by the OM campaign. Sadly for the Swedes they may well have persuaded shareholders that more value can be wrung out of the exchange than either the incumbent management has yet achieved (not difficult) or that they themselves have put on the table. But if exchange shareholders do spurn the Swedish overtures - as they should - what then? The stock exchange has, finally, shown a degree of energy and robust thinking in its defence against OM.

What is clear is that if it does escape the bid it cannot rest on its laurels. The exchange needs a strategy to meet the demands of the big players in the equities game. That will mean, at the very least, new partners, new relationships. At the same time it needs to keep the smaller broker-shareholders on board. That is not impossible.

But the exchange will need to be more aware, more astute and more diplomatic than it has been in the past if it is to prevent a tranche of the membership turning luddite. Otherwise it may find another bidder on the doorstep or, worse still, that it turns into a wallflower at the bourses ball watching its business waltz away.

Clever lender

A top-of-the-cycle air is hanging over the mortgage market: house prices have topped out, the government is worried about "irresponsible lending" and lenders are getting cleverer. Maybe too clever.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia has joined the growing list of lenders offering "flexible" mortgages which allow homeowners to overpay or underpay their mortgages according to their personal circumstances.

These also present a seductive temptation: get into financial difficulties, and stop payments for a couple of months. Before long the mortgage is an overdraft facility.

Dangerous stuff given that total consumer debt has jumped by a quarter in the past three years; the savings ratio is at its lowest level since the Lawson boom. The likelihood of these new style loans being paid off early rather than late is low.

The sister product to flexible mortgages is all-in-one accounts - current account, mortgage, savings and credit card all wrapped into one. On paper they work fine but again the house becomes a cheque book.

Such schemes are highly popular in Australia - one in three Aussies run them - yet Commonwealth Bank is hesitant about bringing them to Britain although Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland and other banks are known to be considering new launches shortly.

On Monday a government-ordered "debt summit" will take place. While this new market should not be choked off, it may be time to ensure lenders make clear the downside to these enticing products, and put in place controls to check that individuals do not use them to spiral further into debt.

The brief is for two minutes at the outside: and it must be topical. I make the half-hour drive to the local radio studio, arriving at 6.35 in the morning. My slot is at 6.45 and, passing through the empty city centre, I feel sure that this Topical Thought, which I am happy to do, remains in the schedule purely as a sop to the church lobby.

To present something broadly religious at 6.45am is safe for the radio station because very few people are listening. But at midnight last night, I sat mouthing my 360 words to a stopwatch like a silent madman in a forgotten corner of a mental ward.

In the studio, I do my bit with all the energy I can muster. I have remembered that, to one listener, I am an intimate companion as they surface from the deep bliss of sleep. To another, I am a distant voice to accompany the morning thunder of the plumbing, or a watery burble as lather is scraped from a face. To others, I am a background to the crunch of cornflakes, or a noise in the car, droning on as they reverse into the road.

Some of my friends think I am mad to make this 36-mile drive for just two minutes on the wireless. A 6.45 slot certainly is marginalised - and what can you say in such a short time?

God does not get much of a profile on our local breakfast show but, up and down the country, the picture varies widely. Some stations still have a God slot every day; in others, the contribution is appreciated so much that it gets replayed later in the show. Whatever happens, I am also aware that even if only 500 people are listening, it is still far more than many clergy see on Sunday. And even at 6.45am, I am keeping the rumour of God alive on a weekday.

But what can I say in that significant 360 words? Nobody wants to hear a theological treatise or a sermon. But more will identify with my Christian perspective than any producer dares imagine. I cannot moralise or evangelise, and, in truth, I do not want to do either - although the station manager probably fears I might. Harassed managers, qualified to analyse listener figures and sum up the opposition, are often out of touch with the spiritual need of their constituents.

Equally, there will be those within the church ready to dismiss my efforts savagely with, "You'd think the Cross never happened" or "Why won't he just talk straight about sin and justification?"

The answer is that these short "thought" slots are still a gift to the church and other faith communities prepared to train people to deal with them properly. They are not given for use as free advertising space, for proselytism or idealistic propaganda. They must be used for one simple purpose: to make people think.

People of faith, be they Christian or of any other religious tradition, come to the business of life in ways coloured by their perceptions of God. They communicate best when they tell relevant stories full of human interest, stories about people and events which relate both to the reality of their listeners' lives and to the reality they know through their relationship with God.

It is hard to forget the more lurid comments of breakfast show producers following contributions from well-known Christians - usually along the lines of "God, that was so boring" - so a few pointers might be useful.

The Topical Thought must never bore. It must stimulate reflection: "Hey! I've not heard that angle before". It must reflect the gravitas of the day's news - offering a light touch, perhaps but never trivial. It must be satisfying to hear; first thing in the morning is no time for cleverness.

It must not sound as if it is only for "people in the know". Christian culture uses words like "sin" and "redemption", which only have meaning within the church. Even words like "peace" and "love" are often used in ways only meaningful to insiders. The Topical Thought must seek to identify with those who might be listening, but on their terms, not on mine.

To my mind, the early morning drive is worth the effort not because my words will suddenly transport anyone to the Damascus Road, although a process may start which could lead eventually to significant change in someone's life. It is bigger than that, and has a more far-reaching prophetic edge.

It is worth doing because it ensures that a tiny voice is heard crying in the wilderness of the airwaves that God is still a vital companion in everyday life for countless thousands of ordinary people.

Mark Rudall is development worker for the Oxford-based Churches Media Trust

The lawyer Charles Rembar, who has died aged 85, won some of the most important censorship cases in America, defending the publishers of Lady Chatterley's Lover, Tropic Of Cancer and Fanny Hill. In each case, he argued that the artistic merit of the books outweighed any possible obscenity and should be protected by the first amendment of the US constitution.

When he set up his practice in New York, after serving in the second world war, one of his first clients was his cousin, Norman Mailer, whose novel, The Naked And The Dead (1948), had its publishers worried about earthy expletives. Rembar suggested "fug" was a phonetically close, but legally safe, alternative.

Later, he became involved in a legal wrangle over another Mailer novel, The Deer Park (1955). It had been accepted for publication, and typeset, by Rinehart & Co, who then decided that it was unpublishable because it was obscene. They subsequently claimed that the obscenity of the book made the contract invalid. Rembar disagreed, and was willing to test his ideas in court. Faced with a potentially costly suit, Rinehart paid Mailer his contracted advance and let the book go to GP Putnam's Sons, where it became a bestseller.

The Lady Chatterley trials began in 1959 when Grove Press, always at the forefront of publishing contentious or avant-garde literature in America, produced an unexpurgated edition of DH Law- rence's novel, which was, at the time, banned in the US in all but a bowdlerised version.

Copies sold via the Readers Subscription Book Club were detained by the American postal authorities (which they were, arguably, entitled to do under the 19th-century Comstock Act). After arguing their case within the post office's own judiciary system - and losing - Rembar and Grove filed a suit against Robert Christenberry, the New York city postmaster. The New York courts found in favour of Grove Press, and an appeal brought by the federal government affirmed the decision. (In England, Penguin Books followed Grove's lead and, in 1960, successfully defended Lady Chatterley's honour in one of Britain's most celebrated court cases.)

In 1961, Grove was in even deeper trouble with Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer. Rather than defending a single summons, the publishers found themselves helping to defend more than 60 cases brought against booksellers all across the US. Although not involved in any of the local cases, Rembar successfully argued two appeals, in Massachusetts and New Jersey. A suit bought against Miller, and a conspiracy charge against Grove Press and publisher Barney Rossett, was dropped before it got to court.

In 1965, Putnam's public- ation of John Cleland's Memoirs Of A Woman Of Pleasure, better known as Fanny Hill, saw Rembar defending the book all the way to the US supreme court. With the overturning of a temporary restraint against the book in New York, sales rocketed, but Rembar found himself on more uncertain ground when he tried to argue the literary merit of the book and its author's intent in writing it.

On publication, in the mid-18th century, Cleland, broke and facing debtor's prison, had written the novel and sold it outright for £20, which made any attempted defence that he had crafted the novel with serious literary intentions patently absurd. The eventual decision of the supreme court was six to three in the publisher's favour.

Rembar's book on these cases, optimistically titled The End Of Obscenity (1968), was a mixture of court testimony, history and sharp, sometimes amusing, asides into the history of American law. It won the George Polk Memorial Award for the best book of 1968. The New York Times reviewer wrote that Rembar had talked the US courts into "capsizing more than a century of court-blessed censorship."

Rembar himself was no mean writer, contributing to the Atlantic Monthly, New Republic and Esquire magazines. His collection of essays, Perspective, appeared in 1975, and, five years later, came a history of the evolving American legal system, The Law Of The Land.

In the latter, Rembar incisively explained the most complex laws, complaining that "for centuries, our lawyers, a priestly caste, used a mysterious tongue, composed of Latin, French, English, incantation and a bit of mumbling. These continue, more or less, to the present day - Latin less, English more, French absorbed, incantation down a bit, mumbling steady". He had a shrewd ear for a soundbite, none better than his claim that "pornography is in the groin of the beholder".

The son of a hotelier, Rembar was raised in New Jersey and educated at Harvard and Columbia University law school. Before the war, he worked for the New Deal agencies and the Office of Price Administration in Washington. As well as his work in court, he also represented many leading literary figures, including Mailer, Herman Wouk, Saul Steinberg and Tom Clancy.

Until he fell ill last July, Rembar continued to attend his New York practice every day. He is survived by his wife and two sons.

 Charles Remar, lawyer and author, born March 12 1915; died October 24 2000.

Autumn always brings out the big editorial guns, and on the criminal front it's a veritable battle of the heavyweights. The struggle for the reader's hard-earned cash sees Evanovich, Muller and Walters in the pink corner versus Leonard, Parker, Lansdale and Friedman in the blue corner.

When it comes to fighting prose, no one approaches the venerable Elmore Leonard. With Pagan Babies (Viking, £16.99), his 36th novel, he is on majestic form, juggling his deceptively colloquial style with darker-than-usual subject matter; the result is a winner by knockout. Father Terry Dunn returns home to Detroit from Rwandan atrocities and meets up with Debbie Dewe, an ex-con working in stand-up comedy. They soon hit it off in a big way (Terry is not that priestly) and also discover a shared talent for making money. However, the Detroit mafia stands in their way. With whiplash action and sparkling repartee, this is Leonard at his coolest and best for years: the undoubted champion of American hardboiled prose.
Buy it at BOL

Boston private eye Sunny Randall makes her second appearance in Robert B Parker's Perish Twice (John Murray, £16.99). This new adventure sees her perfecting the art of multitasking: protecting a lesbian activist from a stalker, dealing with friends' and relatives' crumbling marriages and falling back into bed with her own ex, despite his mob connections. Striking an uneasy balance between job and personal life, Randall is a classic female sleuth, but despite the tight, controlled plot, one feels Parker is coasting on past success.
Buy it at BOL

Meanwhile, racing in overdrive from his Texas gonzo corner comes young pretender Joe R Lansdale with The Bottoms (Gollancz, £16.99), an evocative Depression- era mystery that draws on Texas folk tales and plunges into gothic darkness. The elderly Harry Collins remembers his youthful discovery of the mutilated body of a young black woman on the banks of the Sabine River. His father, both town barber and constable, endeavoured to solve the crime but managed only to upset the racial apple cart. Part horror mystery (with legendary local bogeyman, the Goat Man, lurking in the wings), part coming-of-age tale, this is a wonderful evocation of times and ghosts past, in the tradition of To Kill a Mockingbird. A winner on points by a large margin.
Buy it at BOL

Lighter fare comes with The Mile High Club (Faber, £5.99) by Kinky Friedman, the maverick country-and-western singer turned crime writer who never passes up a pun or a scabrous situation. The irreverent caper begins when the author's namesake meets a femme fatale on a plane and is left holding her cosmetics bag at the airport when she disappears. Assisted by his sidekicks, the Village Irregulars, the Kinkster is soon on the bawdy trail and knee-deep in the customary manure. An infectious ride with smiles to spare, it's a satisfying technical knockout. Give the man a cigar.
Buy it at BOL

And how do the women of the killing fields respond? With talent, elegance and wit, Janet Evanovich's Hot Six (Macmillan, £14.99) sees the return of big-hair New Jersey bounty hunter Stephanie Plum and consolidates the author's title as undisputed queen of the comedy beat. Stephanie is again lumbered with man trouble: fellow bounty hunter Ranger, on the run from a murder rap, leaves her loyalties to law and lust severely tested; then there's sexy vice cop Joe Morelli and a certain orange dog who howls when left alone. What is a gal to do? A hilarious rollercoaster ride with a heroine who would have Bridget Jones for breakfast.
Buy it at BOL

Assuredly more serious and socially committed is Marcia Muller's sleuthette Sharon McCone in Listen To The Silence (Women's Press, £6.99), in which the Californian investigator follows a trail of evil to a Montana Indian reservation and into a web of intrigue and repressed emotions. Humane crime writing in touch with the inner devils of today's society, this will grow on you while you least suspect it. A winner by stealth.
Buy it at BOL

Minette Walters's The Shape of Snakes (Macmillan, £16.99) begins in 1978's winter of discontent and binds the death of a black woman in a rain-soaked gutter with the life of the young white woman who discovers her corpse. First-person narrative and documents combine in a complex psychological story with hidden depths. Not completely convincing, but still superior to the careful cosiness of most contemporary British mysteries.
Buy it at BOL

Wherever Green Is Worn

Tim Pat Coogan

746pp, Hutchinson

£25
Buy it at BOL

The English colonised most of the world, turning the map pink. The Irish have peopled the world, ensuring every country has its patches of green. In the process, the descendants of English colonisers have all but vanished; they may know their lineage but, if they care at all, find it largely irrelevant. They are Americans and Australians and South Africans now; there isn't any lingering affection for the old country. The same could never be said of the émigré Irish, who proudly proclaim their hyphenated status. They are Irish first, regardless of the generations that have passed since their ancestors set sail from Erin's green shores (and ballads with lines like that are just one example of the way in which they ensure that Ireland remains part of their continuing consciousness).

Tim Pat Coogan's exploration of the itinerant Irish who span the globe is part history, part contemporary cultural study and part political tract. It is amusing, interesting and often absorbing, but despite its length, intelligence and wit it doesn't really answer the key questions. Why is the vast Irish diaspora still so committed to Ireland? Why have they maintained the religion and the culture? Why the maudlin sentiment about a homeland that has - for so many - never been their home?

On Coogan's journey through Irish pubs, clubs and embassy dining halls, from Auckland to Paris to San Francisco, we meet scores of expatriate Irish who have prospered in their new lands but have never sought to cut the umbilical cord with Ireland. So powerful is its hold that even those who marry people from different backgrounds manage to impose within their "mixed" family a strong sense of Ireland. I recently met a distant cousin of my wife's, whose grandmother emigrated to Philadelphia in 1904. She married a man who believes his background to be Swiss. Yet their children have been raised as if they are Irish-Americans, able to recite Yeats, knowing the words to scores of Irish songs and sticking fast to the Roman Catholic faith.

This has nothing to do with the conflict in Northern Ireland; they are not politically active. For them, as for so many of their ilk, the romantic attachment to Ireland has been part of their upbringing. Nor does it stem from ignorance. They have made many visits to the country of their ancestors and are well aware that modern Ireland is nothing like John Ford's representation in The Quiet Man (and never really was anyway).

In my progress through Coogan's impressive range of interviewees I searched in vain for an explanation of some kind. I readily admit that this didn't spoil the journey: there is much to enjoy along the way, and it is peppered with the kind of Irish humour that can make you laugh out loud. Coogan tells of a visit to a Gaelic Athletics Association football pitch notorious for its poor facilities. Having looked in vain for somewhere to wash, he asked one of the organisers: "Where are the showers?" The man, pointing to some approaching black clouds, replied: "You'll get plenty of showers when those come over." In Buenos Aires, where a sizeable Irish community flourishes, Coogan discovered that during the Falklands war a group of Argentinian patriots had blown up a bust of Padraig Pearse, one of the leaders of the 1916 Easter Rising, mistaking him for a British hero. In New Orleans, he reports, the tradition in the St Patrick's Day parade is for revellers on the floats to throw the contents of an Irish stew at spectators.

It isn't all fun, export Guinness and uplifting rags-to-riches stories. A section on a priest savagely tortured in Argentina is but one example of the extraordinary heroism exhibited by many Irish missionaries down the years. There are also reminders of the hostility faced by Irish immigrants, especially in Britain in the 1950s, who were met by notices outside lodging houses that read "No Irish need apply" and often "No Irish. No blacks. No dogs." Yet Coogan does not hide the other side of the coin, pointing to instances of anti-black racism by the Irish in the States, relating tales of gangsterism in south Boston and the bending of the democratic will once the Irish gained control of Tammany Hall. Sometimes the Irish fought dirty to win the recognition they now enjoy in both America and Australia.

With the rise of the Celtic tiger and the declining birth rate, emigration has fallen away in recent years. That is good for Ireland, of course, but it means the rest of the world is bound to be a slightly poorer place without its regular green influx. Still, there are 70 million people outside Ireland laying claim to be Irish - and that's quite enough to be going on with, is it not?

Russell Banks's characters tend to be called "trailer trash", but it's a phrase you'll despise after reading his fiction. His new short-story retrospective, The Angel on the Roof, sinks especially deep into the ice-bound aloneness of small towns and trailer parks in upstate New Hampshire and New York, the American North Country he's staked as his own. We see the inhabitants of one lakeside terminus from a dozen angles, each enriching the pride, idiocy, selfishness, sympathy, nobility and wreckage-clinging survived despair to be found in such lost corners.

In the novel Continental Drift (1985), the careening effort by Bob Dubois to escape his caged small-town prospects tears him away from himself and his family, and leads to devastating loss. In Rule of the Bone (1995), a teenage boy's need to out-race alienation and parental abuse spins him off America's edge. The busload of drowned, frozen schoolchildren in The Sweet Hereafter (1997) and the middle-aged man doomed by his drunk, violent father's example in Affliction (1989) - both recently adapted as Oscar-winning films - show abandonment from other angles, a genetic flaw in America's heart. Banks knows this whole story. Born in New Hampshire, he's fought off his own violent father's example, freed himself from a fated life with fiction. He knows his subjects aren't a Jerry Springer freak show. They're humanity.

"There's an important tradition in American writing," the 60-year-old says, in the upstate New York small town where he now lives, when not teaching at Princeton, "going back to Mark Twain and forward to Raymond Carver and Grace Paley, whose work is generated by love of people who are scorned and derided. The people I'm writing about are the ones you normally don't feel affection for when you see them in the street or the shopping mall. I have an almost simple-minded affection for them. My readers are not the same as my characters, as I'm very aware. So I'm glad when they feel that affection too."

Vann, in the story "Plains of Abraham", stands for almost all Banks's male characters: "a complex, layered mind with only a few compartments connected". Alienated from his culture and class, unable to understand his own nature, he has no way out. "I think that's particularly true of men," Banks says. "They feel their lives are being mysteriously controlled by forces they can't even name. As a defence they compartmentalise their experience into little boxes that don't communicate, because the truth is too painful. At some point, they hear rapping through the walls of those boxes, and they start to realise something's deeply wrong. Most of my male characters then struggle back to some place in their past, to find when the light at tunnel's end dimmed."

Banks's life was like that of his own future characters until his mid-twenties, fitted to the shape set for him: wife at 18 (first of four), baby at 19, divorced at 20, a small-town New Hampshire pipe-fitter in a pick-up truck. It was writing's discipline - Jack Kerouac's harsh background and the paternal friendship of Nelson Algren were among his inspirations - that plucked him to a different life. But this uprooting left guilty scars on work that was at first constrained, in denial. "I felt I'd betrayed my past and the people who made it up. My writing was in a netherland: fearful of my own sources, of myself, till my mid-thirties, when I accepted them."

The source that was most difficult to admit was his father, a violent drunk who abandoned the family when Banks was 12, and around whom he was physically anxious even in the man's old age. "He remains the centre of my imaginative life. He wasn't just a violent, alcoholic brute, no one is. He died in 1979, and yet he appears in my dreams two or three times a week, as he was in his mid-forties, when he was at his most powerful. He left a residue of violence my neurons are still patterned around. It's trauma that rewires them, usually. Goodness never provides a trauma. Violence does. Abandonment does. Betrayal does. My adult life has been lucky, people have been faithful and loving. So my wiring's the same."

"The Visit", in which a successful middle-aged man revisits a childhood home electrified with shadowy, threatening memories, is also Banks's attempt to invoke what he calls the "heat and light" of violence, "its erotic charge, its intensity of attention", for both victim and victimiser - a seduction that he later sought out in senseless bar-room fights which would have left him dead if writing hadn't stepped in. Affliction's paternal tragedy was his fictional goodbye to all that. "I was glad I wrote that story. It meant I wouldn't have to again."

The Sweet Hereafter and Rule of the Bone instead focused on 1990s children: Nicole in one, Bone in the other, both sexually abused. The former's schoolbus, in which a town's children sink inexorably away from their parents through cracked ice, is later a refuge from parents for Bone, abandonment unbroken. Recently, Cloudsplitter (1999), about violent Abolitionist John Brown, investigated racism's stain.

Banks, meanwhile, is back where he started, in a working-class small town. "I had to will myself back. But these people are my birthright. Writing saved me by letting me leave once. But I can never go too far. All the truth I know is here."

Tom Clancy was always something of a cold war man, and given its absence he does the next best thing: makes up another one, this time China versus the USA, with Russia in the middle. Russia, in economic disarray, has discovered large deposits of oil and gold in Siberia. China, being cash-poor after an overspend on defence, is keen to settle a trade agreement with the US, although there are diplomatic complications. China is in dispute over US recognition of Taiwan, while its own record on human rights and enforced population control is deplored in the west.

Meanwhile, spies monitor each other's secrets and the Americans achieve a notable coup with the penetration of a top-level Chinese secretary. Clancy's scenario is ambitious: to show how the various facets of industry, trade, the military, espionage and government work in foreign affairs, and what happens when the diplomatic process breaks down and military aggression takes over.
