He swirls his coffee and props his chin in his hand, looking unhappy. "I suddenly thought that there's not a day gone by that I haven't had a drink in the past five years. I'd binge for two or three days at a time. And then, as soon as I first tried heroin, I thought, 'Where has this been?' I'd found my private Idaho. What a pain reliever. It made me feel whole, made me feel ..." He pauses, searching for the word.

Warm? He nods emphatically. "It's still crazy for me. I knew smackheads in the [housing] schemes and I used to think, 'I'll never do that', but when I started, I thought, 'This is what it's all about.'" His use quickly escalated. "As soon as I started, I wanted it all the time. I stopped drinking, substituting one for another. It was about self-medicating, making myself numb. I kept piling shite on, piling it on. I felt very dark. At Christmas 1998, I didn't want to be with anyone I knew, so I stayed alone in a cabin. I called my mother and Eileen to wish them happy Christmas and managed to sound happy. But I'd be up at 5am and run out of drugs and be having cold sweats and think, 'Fuck, why am I doing this?' I'd get occasional little moments of clarity and see pain on the faces of my family."

He had tried rehab in the summer of 1998 at the Meadows clinic in Arizona, but bought more drugs the day he left. "They told me that I'd have to commit to a lifetime of sobriety, and I was like, 'Aaaahh!' But I had more knowledge of my disease after that, so using was never the same again. My disease wanted me dead. I was afraid to stand in front of the sun because [I thought] you'd see all my internal organs. Everyone in the Wet Wet Wet camp acknowledged the problem, but I was still in denial."

Then came his collapse at the Conrad Hotel, after which he checked into the Priory and became the latest popster to begin the well-trodden road to recovery. He grins almost fondly. "My charm did not work in the slightest at the Priory. My smile was the first thing to go." He spent six weeks there, and his first act on leaving was to quit the band - against manager Elliot Davies's wishes. "The best chance he has of getting back to his best is to get back to Wet Wet Wet," Davies still maintains a year later. Pellow disagrees.

That he has thrown himself into sobriety is obvious from a vocabulary that's dotted with words such as "sharing" and "co-dependence". Sometimes, he goes to more than one NA meeting a day, and says that he takes his recovery a day at a time. He's been proactive, finding new management and making a new album, which is said to be adult pop with a soulful twist. He recorded it in Memphis with Willie Mitchell, who apparently amused him during the sessions by telling stories about his old buddy Martin Luther King. "The feel is real, it's me. There's a dignity and simplicity to the songwriting I've never had before," he says, relieved to be talking about music, still his chief passion.

Pellow is now a member of that very Y2K club of celebrities who nearly fell off the edge and were pulled back by a combination of therapy and abstinence. His experience has made him a more rounded individual, but for those to whom he'll always be Smiler it is still a shock. If even Smiler couldn't hack success, can any other supposedly wholesome star be quite what they seem?

This autumn is a great time for bargain-hunters. The UK's latest factory shopping village, the McArthurGlen Designer Outlet in Livingston, Scotland, opened this week offering 30%-70% off the normal retail prices of more than 100 well-known brands under one roof plus themed restaurants, an eight-screen cinema and a fitness centre.

Also launched this week was the eighth edition of that bargain-hunter's bible The Good Deal Directory 2001, which provides county-by-county listings of 2,800 factory shops, permanent discount outlets, dress agencies and architectural salvage sites in the UK with money-saving tips on buying top brand names at discount prices.

The book is accompanied by a new website, www.gooddealdirectory.co.uk, which, as well as listing factory villages and other discount outlets, offers the latest news on sales and bargains around the country and a search facility for shoppers trying to track down specific cut-price brand names in their area.

The latest big name to join the discount scene is Marks & Spencer, which is opening its first three factory shops in the next month at Ashford, Kent (November 2), Cheshire Oaks, South Wirral (November 9) and the new Livingston site (November 16).

Among bargains to be had at the M&S cut-price stores will be ladies' silk cashmere cardigans down from £75 to £37.50, men's wool suits down from £150 to £75, ladies' leather shoes down from £35 to £20 and ladies' satin pyjamas down from £25 to £15.

There are about 1,500 individual factory shops in the UK, many of them in isolated spots or on industrial estates, selling manufacturers' surplus stock - cancelled orders, returned merchandise, over-production, seconds and discontinued lines - at prices much below those in the high street shops which the factory supplies.

"Discounts vary, but in general they are higher in the fashion sector, where an outfit can become out of date very quickly and where mark-ups can be as high as 280%, and lower in ceramics and glassware," says Noelle Walsh, author of The Good Deal Directory. "The older the item is, the cheaper the price. As a general rule, you can expect at least 30% off and up to 80%."

In the 90s developers started gathering together lots of these shops on one site in factory shopping villages ranging in size from K Village in Kendal, Cumbria, with a dozen shops, to McArthurGlen's Cheshire Oaks village in South Wirral with more than 150. With new villages due to open during 2001 at Harwich in Essex, Lichfield in the west midlands and at Salford Quays in Manchester, there will be at least 35 by the end of next year.

Best for label snobs and fashion aficionados, according to Noelle Walsh, is Bicester Village in Oxfordshire, boasting more than 70 shops with prices reduced by up to 60%, and McArthurGlen's York outlet, currently with 75 shops and 150 more planned.

Home-loving families looking for children's wear should head for Clarks Village at Street in Somerset and McArthurGlen villages in Swindon and Cheshire Oaks.

And if you want to combine bargain shopping with a fun day out for the family, best bets will be the Clacton Factory Outlet Village in Essex and the Freeport Shopping Village in Fleetwood, Lancashire, which both have seaside locations offering plenty of leisure facilities such as children's play areas and rides.

Top tips for factory shop bargain hunters

Visit villages if possible on a week day when things are quiet - 80% of factory village shopping customers visit on a weekend.

Although they don't advertise the fact, most factory villages slash prices still further at traditional high street sale times - January and June/July. The downside is that your choice of lines will be more limited at sale times.

Best buys are always the more expensive items. So use factory shopping as a chance to "go up a brand" from those you can normally afford.

Turnover is usually very fast. So if you like something, buy it; you are unlikely to find it again.

Carry the measurements of rooms, windows and family members with you so that you are prepared to snap up bargains as and when you spot them.

Never travel a long way without phoning first to check opening hours and directions. If you are after particular brand names, also check first on stock levels.

When buying discounted goods, you have the same rights under the Sale of Goods Act 1979 and the Consumer Protection Act 1987 as you would in mainstream shops.

Check if an item is a sec ond. You'll usually find a label on the garment stating why this is so. Although your statutory rights are in place at factory shops, you can't return a second because of a fault indicated at the outset.

Items are not always as flatteringly presented as in high street stores, so be prepared to rummage.

If you are looking for the height of fashion, factory shopping isn't for you. But factory shopping is great for children's clothes, jeans, leisure wear, sweaters, underwear and classic items which don't date such as blazers, coats and raincoats.

Spirits group Allied Domecq has agreed a deal worth more than $1bn (£700m) to take control of the Captain Morgan rum brand in a move that puts it in pole position in the auction for Canadian group Seagram's drinks business.

Captain Morgan is at present produced by a Puerto Rican firm, Destileria Serralles, but distributed and marketed worldwide by Seagram.

In the event of a change of ownership of Seagram, the Puerto Rican firm has first refusal to buy back the rights to the rum.

Under the terms of yesterday's agreement Destileria Serralles will exercise its right to snatch full control of Captain Morgan, irrespective of the outcome of the battle to buy Seagram.

It will then sell on the international rights to Allied Domecq.

Allied's chief executive, Philip Bowman, said: "I've always said that in our brand portfolio we don't have a dark rum and we don't have a vodka. This fills a gap.

"Captain Morgan is a large brand and it's been showing very significant growth, particularly over the last five years." Captain Morgan is considered one of the jewels in the crown of Seagram's £4.5bn drinks business, which also includes Chivas Regal whisky and Martell cognac.

Allied Domecq is battling to buy Seagram's portfolio but faces stiff opposition from a joint bid by Diageo and Pernod Ricard.

Seagram's founders, the Bronfman family, are also planning a bid but are seen as outsiders.

At the least, yesterday's deal will give Allied a consolation prize if it looses out on the bidding for the rest of Seagram.

Palestinian leaders trying to give some direction to the bloody protests that have gone on for a month said yesterday they were gearing up for an even more violent struggle against Israel, including attacks on military posts and suicide bombings.

In the last fortnight, popular leaders from Yasser Arafat's Fatah organisation have joined hands with Hamas and Islamic Jihad to try to steer their followers away from the unequal confrontations between stone-throwing teenagers and troops armed with high-velocity rifles and backed up by tanks and helicopter gunships, which have killed more than 130 people, almost all Palestinians.

Yesterday, as Israeli forces split Gaza in two, tearing out trees and sealing the main road at Kfar Darom near the site of a suicide bomb attack two days ago, Mr Arafat's chief lieutenant in the territory said he was under growing pressure to deploy Fatah's armed activists, the tanzim, in expectation of an Israeli attack.

"When the decision comes, the only choice will be to use the military, and all Palestinians will be behind that choice," said Ahmed Hillis, the Gaza leader of Fatah. "I believe we are moving closer and closer to violence."

The spur for the transformation of the Jerusalem-centred intifada (uprising) into an armed struggle was Thursday's suicide bombing in Gaza. The bomber, who cycled up to an Israeli post, failed to kill, or seriously wound, a single soldier. But the crowds jostling to touch his casket at his funeral in Gaza hailed him as a martyr yesterday.

A bearded leader of the Islamic Jihad, perched on a lorry leading the procession, told the crowds that Nabil al-Araeer had not died in vain. "Don't believe the media," he yelled through a megaphone. "He killed at least four soldiers, and wounded 10."

At the burial ground, he read out the suicide note left by the kindergarten worker. "Thank God I am headed where I have always wanted to go."

That was no consolation for Nabil's father, Faraj al-Araeer, a broken man slumped in a plastic chair outside his Gaza home. "I never knew who he was," he said. "It must have been the new situation, with all the violence. He was planning to go to university."

He sighed. "I have my goals, and he had his goal. We are completely different."

As thousands watched the funeral crowds, some clasping grenades and the black flags of the Islamic Jihad, only a few dared to question Araeer's sacrifice. "This was a suicide for nothing. He died for nothing," said Nahid Eyada, who owns a flour mill next to the Araeer family home. As other shops downed their shutters in honour of the dead bomber, his stayed defiantly open.

"Look at what is going to happen. Other people are going to die. The leaders send them to kill themselves, and they sit on their plush chairs," he said. "There has to be another way."

But those options are shrinking. Yesterday's funeral was broadcast on Palestinian official television, further evidence of the alliance between Fatah, and the Islamic militants whose opposition to the peace process once made them hunted men in Gaza.

For five years, the intelligence services of the Palestinian Authority did Israel's work, locking up bombers and other Islamic militants without trial. But two weeks ago, some 40 Hamas militants were released in Gaza, and at least five or six are still at large.

On Sunday, CIA officials told the Palestinian Authority to hand over the activists within 24 hours. The security services refused, at the risk of a rupture in their relations with Washington.

"I don't think that after the Israeli attacks, and this emergency situation that they have time to look for anybody," said Ismail Abu Shanab, a leading Hamas figure in Gaza. "They do not feel any longer that these Hamas prisoners are a danger to the Palestinian Authority."

Although Fatah and the Islamist groups are presenting a united front, deep divisions remain on tactics.

Hamas preaches that any Israeli, civilian or soldier, in the West Bank, Gaza or inside the borders of the Jewish state, is fair game. "Anyone who carries a gun, and shoots at an Israeli target can do it on his own, and at a suitable time for him," said Abu Shanab.

Fatah is adamant there be no operations inside Israel, for fear of provoking harsh reprisals on the Palestinian population. But Mr Hillis admits that Fatah does not have absolute control; that was the message of Thursday's bombing.

"You have to understand that the intifada is no respecter of rules, and if someone wants to die nobody can stop that."

Lord Pitkerro drew the curtains to block out the press pack camped outside his house. He had said enough yesterday, and the era of the mobile phone was over.

For the hundredth time, he thought over what he and his fellow scientists had told the government. Had they taken caution too far? Had it been right, on virtually no evidence, to recommend banning mobile phone use for the under-18s and setting a five minute a day limit for adults? Had it been right to call for the dismantling of all phone antennae within a kilometre of inhabited buildings, rendering mobiles all but useless? True, nobody knew if they were safe, but nobody knew they weren't - yet.

The Today programme said something about a financial crash brought about by the collapse in telecoms shares. In Finland, home of Nokia, the government had resigned. The papers were calling the Pitkerro report "the safety culture gone mad". The US and EU were denouncing him, even as skipfuls of British mobiles headed for the scrapheap.

Well, one day they would thank him. Perhaps.

It hasn't happened that way, of course. The real report this year into mobile phone safety, chaired by the former government chief scientist Sir William Stewart, hedged its bets on mobiles and masts by saying there was a faint risk of a risk, but did not call for any serious curbs on their use.

Yet as the public asks in the wake of the BSE inquiry whether they can trust scientists to give it to them straight, fast and accurate on what is safe and what is not, it is worth considering how great the shock would have been if, in the late 1980s, the government's scientific advisers had recommended taking all the anti-BSE measures taken after 1996.

Now we have come to terms with the vast pyres of cattle and the devastation of the British beef industry, because now we know BSE kills people. But how would a scientific panel's recommendation to slaughter hundreds of thousands of cows have gone down in, say, 1989, when cartoonists were still joshing about mad cows thinking they were Napoleon, and the rightwing press was railing against European attempts to ban "our beef"?

John Adams, professor of geography at University College London and a specialist in risk, pointed out just how thin the scientific evidence was in the early days for a risk to humans from BSE.

He said there were three categories of risk: directly perceptible risk, such as when food smells off; risks perceived through science, such as when scientists warn of a danger of HIV being spread through blood transfusion; and virtual risk. "Virtual risk is where scientists confess ignorance or reputable scientists are disputing with each other about what's going on," he said. "These are where you find the most acrimonious, longest running debates. BSE, for much of the controversy, was in this category."

"What, with the benefit of foresight, looked like a risk worth taking looks with hindsight and a clever lawyer like culpability. We have to make decisions about what to do on the basis of all this very unsatisfactory evidence. When something does go wrong, the mist clears and all other variables we were worried about drop away and leave a clear trail back to the culprit."

All very well, but it does not let scientists off the hook. What they are under fire for in the BSE case is less their pure scientific method, or even their conclusions, than the way they allowed themselves and their opinions to be manipulated by civil servants.

Why did they not push harder and shout louder to get more research funds to fill in the blank spots in our knowledge of BSE? Why did they not state more clearly the limits of their knowledge in the fields concerned and draw in experts from elsewhere?

Alan Dickinson, now retired, was director of the neuropathogenesis unit in Edinburgh from 1981 to 1987 and is a top specialist in the family of diseases to which BSE belongs. He was never asked to join the government's advisory teams.

"The public should be wary of what the civil servants call experts," he said. "Almost all the plethora of committees set up were populated by people who had no more idea than the man in the moon about the subject."

Scientists and politicians had one thing in common: they stood or fell by their deeds. Bureaucrats did not. "Politicians are just pawns in the hands of any civil servant who wishes to manipulate them. Science's strength is that people stick their names to what they believe to be the truth, and the whole design of democracy is dependent on named politicians ... If we don't design a system where civil servants have to put their names to what they do, we'll never get to the heart of this."

As the Tory government's chief scientific adviser from 1990 to 1995, Sir William Stewart escaped with light burns from the BSE debacle, but in his report on the safety of mobile phones this year he was careful. "We conclude," the key passage of the report said, "that it is not possible at present to say that exposure to [mobile phone radiation], even at levels below national guidelines, is totally without potential adverse health effects, and that the gaps in knowledge are sufficient to justify a precautionary approach."

In other words, we don't know whether mobiles are dangerous. Frustrating for the public, confusing; but honest, accurate and true to science. It is this message, say scientists, that should have emerged from science advisers in the early years of the BSE crisis - and would have, had they not allowed themselves to be used.

"Policymakers can't always assume scientists can give them precise advice," said Roy Anderson, professor of infectious disease epidemiology at Imperial College and a relatively recent recruit to the government's ranks of BSE advisers. "Scientists have to be prepared to say: 'We do not know.'"

Why are British scientists apparently ready to let Whitehall turn their uncertainty into certainty - as in the BSE case, where the Southwood committee's "remote risk" of harm to humans from eating beef turned into the government's "beef is perfectly safe"?

David Tyrell, former head of the government's second set of BSE science advisers, Seac, admitted to the inquiry: "We'd given up the idea of trying to stand back and evaluate science from a distance and impartially. I think that's part of what we got ourselves into, willy nilly."

Prof Adams said that when scientists began to cohabit with bureaucrats and politicians they started to adopt their ways. They "start thinking about how to form advice in the way that will actually make something happen. If they thought that going one step further would be dismissed, they back off."

Ah, the fear of not being asked back - the carrot and stick of patronage. Many scientists mutter that political control over research funds, greatly strengthened in the 1980s, gives government an instrument to intimidate scientists into telling them what they want to hear.

Nor are research funds and jobs the only form of patronage. Britain offers scientists the politically directed honour of a knighthood or a peerage.

"If you're regarded as a safe pair of hands and not one to rock the boat you're more likely to get public honours," said a scientist who asked not to be named. "That's the perception ... There can be penalties for being very open and honest."

One of the most damning criticisms of the Southwood committee and the bureaucrats who worked with it is that they failed to acknowledge the limits of their expertise. They did not submit their work to a review by other scientists.

If you look at the research papers being published in the scientific journals today, two things strike you. One is that, as the targets of our understanding become more ambitious, it takes ever more resources to make each tiny incremental advance towards them; the other is how often institutes from more than one country are involved in the breakthroughs. It is not just that these are bad times for lone scientific geniuses: they are bad times for flagwaving about "our" scientists.

In a sense there are no scientists any more, only specialists in different, narrowing branches of science. The lessons of the scientific response to the BSE crisis are that scientists have to do more to acknowledge publicly the fragmented, international nature of their profession, and not to let governments get away with glib phrases such as "our top scientists."

It would help - the Phillips report makes this point - if the government had a single chief scientific officer, with a contingency budget, to knock the heads together of in-house scientists from rival ministries, send out for the right advisers, and fund fast-track research.

Scientists complain that the media distort their message or play scientists off against each other. Certainly the media like to jump out of the cupboard and shout "Boo!" at the public. Who can forget the Sun's miracle of front page compression a few days after the Chernobyl disaster? "Six million red babes may die" - horror, pity, anti-communism and bad science, all in eight syllables.

Yet note the "may". Even the tabloid's tabloid was prepared to embrace the precautionary principle. Perhaps the scientists could get their message across better, if only they spoke the media's language.

"In the education of scientists, there should be a stronger emphasis on presenting complex information simply," said Prof Anderson.

British scientists have warned us that smoking kills since the 1950s, but people are still buying cigarettes, getting lung cancer, and dying. Prof Adams pointed out that the public wanted scientific clarity on beef or mobiles or long distance air travel not to see these things removed from society, but so they could choose whether to use them. It was the sense of risk concealed that gave offence.

"The effect has been devastating," he said. "That loss of public confidence is likely to be the most significant cost of this affair."

The British science journal Nature said this week that it was not surprising that many scientists in agriculture kept their heads down in the late 1980s and early 1990s, fearing financial reprisals from a cutting government. They had been wrong.

"We now know the dangers of keeping silent," the journal said. "Of course the main victims are those whose lives have been tragically cut short by a horrific disease. But science, too, has suffered. With ministers having consistently claimed that they were following the best scientific advice, even while subtly misrepresenting its message, scientists have come to be seen by the public as part of the problem. It will take much work to regain public trust."

Hackers have broken into Microsoft's computer network and gained access to blueprints of its latest software, the company admitted yesterday. Initial investigations suggest that the hackers could have links with, or be based in, St Petersburg, Russia.

Microsoft, already embroiled in a legal battle with the US government, said it is working with the FBI and law enforcement authorities to trace the source of "a deplorable act of computer espionage".

Steve Ballmer, the chief executive, confirmed that hackers gained access to the source codes - which include the software for products such as the Windows operating system - but insisted they had not tampered with them.

"They did in fact access the source codes," Mr Ballmer said during a meeting in Stockholm, Sweden. "You bet this is an issue of great importance. I can also assure you that we know that there has been no compromise of the integrity of the source codes, that it has not been tampered with in any way."

The company said consumer, business and government computers running Microsoft software should be safe.

"We're still trying to figure out how it happened," another spokesman said.

The break-in raises fears that companies may be facing greater threats from hackers with a commercial mission than those bound on merely committing mischief. The break-in also raises fears of a "mole" within Microsoft.

Members of Microsoft's security team apparently found that passwords used to transfer the source code behind Microsoft's software were being sent from the company's computer network headquarters in Redmond, Washington state, to an email address in St Petersburg.

The hackers are believed to have had access to the company's software codes for as long as three months.

Internet start-ups are seen as synonymous with youth, with men and women fresh out of business school - or even school - using the web to bypass the traditional hierarchy of the office and become instant senior managers.

But a report issued by the Industrial Society this month says that dot.coms are realising that they need older, more experienced workers once they have launched to take the business from infancy into maturity.

The report, Experience Necessary - the Business Case for Wisdom, has dubbed the type of older business people most in demand as "warhorses"; seasoned campaigners with experience of previous economic cycles who are not scared by downturns. Older people also bring the weight of experi ence, which leads to increased customer confidence, and well-honed networking skills.

The report points in particular to the Asian market, where "veneration and respect for age are important, and counterparts find it more comfortable to build relationships with older business people rather than with young dot.com entrepreneurs".

The view that having a few wrinkles are important in business was supported last week by the British Venture Capitalists Association, whose members underwrite scores of dot.com start-ups with hard cash. The association's chairman, David Thorp, decried the lack of wise heads watching the finances.

"The reason why the early dot.coms seemed to succeed was because they had no bag gage. Everyone was looking with fresh eyes and they went for it; the internet meant that barriers to entry were low and they had speed and verve. But what they did not have was business knowledge, and what we are now seeing is some of the more trusted business skills being integrated into new internet solutions." He adds that most venture capitalists avoided early dot.coms precisely because of their lack of business experience.

This month saw the first high-profile signing of an older business star by his younger peers. Allan Leighton, 47, former chief executive officer of Wal-Mart Europe and Asda before that, is joining the board of lastminute.com. He will not be paid, but is receiving 1m share options for his role as non-executive chairman.

Martha Lane Fox, the 27- year-old chief operating officer of lastminute says: "We are thrilled that someone with Allan's track record of leadership in customer-focused businesses is joining us. Allan is someone we have respected for some time. As we talked to him about our vision it soon became clear that he would be extremely valuable in helping us to provide an even better service for our customers."

Ronald Cohen, of venture capitalists Apax Partners, agrees that dot.coms are waking up to the value of experience. "Young entrepreneurs are coming in and asking for experienced people; increasingly they are realising that they need this to get the business to the stock markets."

And Charlotte Thorne, author of the Industrial Society report, says: "The current requirement is for knowledge. Businesses need people who can employ their experience and understanding, their networks and their strategic vision to add value to organisations." She makes the point that businesses set up by entrepreneurs in their early 50s are twice as likely to survive as those started by people aged 20-25 and that by 2020 one in four of the workforce will be aged 50 or above.

But are those who are bricks and mortar worldly wise readily able to transfer their skills to the virtual realm?

Graham Woolley, aged 54, had spent most of his working life as a management consultant until he went into semi-retirement last year. His CV boasts that he has been director of business solutions at CGNU Insurance, and has also been principal of PricewaterhouseCoopers' management consultancy di vision - and that his skills and experience include analysing problems and issues, creating and implementing original solutions and organising third-party suppliers.

He is now acting as a consultant to FashionNightmare.com, a website which aims to stimulate, educate, entertain and empower female teenagers, launched later this month.

"I was running a project employing Kath's (Kathleen Nickels, founder of FashionNightmare) husband. He said that he thought I was just the kind of person who could help the company get off the ground and I was interested in getting involved in a project. To date I have mainly been involved in forward planning and making sure that services are delivered.

"It's a kind of 'sorting out any messes' role - before me, Kath went to family and friends to try to get issues sorted out, but it is what I have spent most of my career doing. The biggest issue so far for FashionNightmare has been that it has not had enough money."

He is not being paid for his input, but has taken an equity share in the company instead: "I have a much more personal stake than I would have if it was just a matter of investment," he says.

The decision-making process is essentially the same as with a traditional style company, so his experience is directly relevant, and his years in the business world mean that he can play a smoothing role.

Ms Nickels has found that the process of raising money, finding the right team, managing third-party suppliers and actually launching a website has been more torturous than she had expected, even with her strong business background. She says that taking on Mr Woolley was one of the best long-term moves she has made so far in her bid to launch the site.

Although she has been a management consultant - with US group Marakon, working both in the States and the UK, and writing the business model should not have been a problem, she found herself proposing ideas which, as a consultant, she would have pooh-poohed.

"It's amazing, now that I'm on my own, how much self-doubt creeps in and how excited I am when someone thinks what I'm doing is a good idea. Also, I did not go to business school, which is where I think the majority of strong networks are built.

"When you start out there are plenty of cynics, the kind of people who have just got their MBA and need to prove that they know more about the internet than you. They just want to rain on your parade and you need to be able to spot that.

"But what you really need is people who know a lot and will be able to criticise, but their criticism will be constructive."

She adds that Mr Woolley's involvement also encouraged backers. "I had to tell my cousin, who had been helping me out, that her CV was not going to get us funding. It's definitely true that backers will go for an A team with a B idea but never a B team with an A idea.

"But it is a catch 22 situation - you can't get people without funding, but you can't get funding without the people there in the first place."

But most important is the guiding hand of someone used to toughing out hard times in business: "It has been a constantly changing dynamic, like a box of puzzle pieces which keep changing size. It is exhilarating when people promise money or support, but when that then fails to materialise quickly, or at all, the lows are really low. Having Graham around has helped me put it all into perspective."

She would now offer two main pieces of advice to an internet startee: ensure that one of the first members of staff taken on is a technology expert: "I tried to launch without this and failed. I now have a person who has 20 years' experience," she adds.

Secondly, find a mentor and get them on board as a non-executive director. "It helps to have contacts, but it is far more helpful to have advice and cheerleaders."

Windows of opportunity: why even Bill Gates may face an age-old problem in his 30s

Ageism is rife in the IT sector despite huge skills shortages, says a new survey by the Employers' Forum on Age, writes Liz Stuart . Although 65% of the 1,400 IT professionals questioned said their company finds it difficult to recruit staff, more companies are refusing to take on older people, many of whom have the necessary skills. More than four in five thought the government should do more to stop ageism in the workplace.

Sam Mercer, campaign director of the EFA, says the research also shows that 88% of people said mixed-aged teams work better than teams comprised solely of younger workers. "The IT industry is particularly guilty of ageism. An article in a computer trade magazine said all employees over 50 should be sacked because they do not have the right skills, but our survey refutes that.

"The government's immigration initiative could help to close this skills gap but it's not enough on its own. If the government and IT industry are serious about addressing skills shortages they should work towards changing a culture undervaluing the contribution of employees as young as 35."

The research also showed an alarming definition of the term "older": 21% thought an employee is an older worker by the age of 35, which would put Bill Gates in this category.

Even as Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and health minister Alan Milburn were preparing to make their apologies for the failures of successive governments in getting to grips with BSE and its nightmare human form, revealed in the devastating Phillips report into the catastrophe on Thursday, more bad news was being passed on to their officials.

Investigations into the death of a 74-year-old man last year had concluded that he, too, was a victim of vCJD - news that could lead to a fundamental reassessment of the disease.

No wonder then that Mr Brown announced that the government was already "commissioning an independent assessment of current scientific understanding of the disease, including emerging findings, on the origins of the BSE epidemic".

Behind that flat matter-of-fact announcement was a worrying realisation that the Phillips inquiry belief that BSE could have been in cows since the early 1970s - at least three cycles of the infection before it burst in its full horror on to Britain's dairy farms - would mean scientists would have to think yet again about all the potential risks to human health.

Vaccine

Volume eight of the 16-volume report advises the government it may have to check all vaccines made during the 1970s. Bovine material sourced from Britain in the 1980s is now banned but previous, allegedly inadequate checks by medicine control officials between 1988 and 1992 failed to establish the source of bovine ingredients used in the 1970s to develop the master stocks of batches that could have remained in circulation for years.

Now, said Phillips, "batches of vaccines manufactured during the 1970s cannot therefore be ruled out as a source of infection merely because of their date of manufacture. Patients with vCJD born before 1960 are unlikely to have been infected by childhood vaccination, but the possibility of infection by vaccination in adulthood may merit consideration."

The Phillips team, of course, did not know of the 74-year-old. Now people are wondering just how exposed people were to eating infected meat in the 1970s - long before there were any control mea sures to combat the hidden BSE that can exist in infected cattle well in advance of when they display the classic "mad" signs.

Lord Phillips has made clear that however quickly the government had reacted to the cattle epidemic in the 1980s - and it was sometimes painfully slow - it could not have stopped thousands of diseased and infectious cows entering the food chain and infecting unknown members of the population.

Iceberg

That situation is still far from clear in the population. Is this old man just an unusual aberration in the normal profile of vCJD victims? One of the first reasons early cases of the disease came to attention was their relative youth compared to other sufferers of debilitating and fatal neurological conditions.

Analysis of the ages of the first 77 deaths revealed earlier this month indicates that since 1995, a dozen teenagers have succumbed, three dozen aged between 20 and 29, about 20 between 30 and 39, and about 10 others up to the age of 54. The assumption until now has been they were exposed to poisoned bovine material as the epidemic in cattle began to spiral, perhaps between 1984 and 1989. That would suggest relatively short incubation periods for some, around 10 years.

Zoe Williams, still alive at 14, but a known victim of vCJD at 12, would have been just four when the main anti-BSE measures were introduced.

Yet such vCJD-like diseases can have incubation periods running to 25 or even 35 years. Just suppose the new victim was exposed to BSE in the mid-1970s. But would he be the herald of a new "iceberg" or was he just unlucky?

The truth is that no-one yet knows. So much about the disease is still a mystery despite the huge advances of recent years. No-one knows what the level of an infective "dose" is for a human - BSE-infected material the size of a peppercorn was enough for big cows - or the length of incubation; whether genetic make-up makes people more susceptible (all confirmed cases so far have been from the same group that makes up just under 40% of the population) and whether other factors such as youth, illness, sores or even new teeth increase the risk.

The Phillips team also recommends further investigation of the consumption of cheap beefburgers and other meat products made from mechanically recovered meat which, unlike other risky parts of cows, was not banned until 1995. These are now among prime candidates for carrying infectivity, even if no-one knows how much.

Now, the potential exposure to infected meat spreads more than 20 years - from the mid-1970s and mid-1990s.

America's most powerful politician will not be elected next month. For those on the receiving end of US foreign policy, at least, that person, arguably, is Jesse Helms. The hawkish Republican senator from North Carolina is well into his fifth, six-year term. He does not face re-election until 2002. In the meantime, he continues as chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee which, in concert with Congress as a whole, holds the purse strings and has oversight of almost every aspect of US global diplomacy. Nor is Mr Helms at all bashful about exercising his considerable powers or advancing his trenchant opinions.

In the past few weeks alone, Mr Helms has denounced Yasser Arafat as a "terrorist"; dismissed Iranian reform efforts as "hogwash"; described Fidel Castro as a "deadbeat" and "swindler"; condemned normalised trade relations with "communist China"; ridiculed the "sorry performance" of UN peacekeepers in Sierra Leone; blasted the Clinton administration for "inexcusable" delays in building a national missile defence system; and hammered away at the old enemy, Russia.

Thanks in no small measure to Mr Helms, the US has in recent years defaulted on its UN dues, tried to block the planned international criminal court, failed to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, been slow to deploy ground troops in both Bosnia and Kosovo (and whinged about it ever since), imposed sanctions on dozens of countries it dislikes, pursued a fruitless, destructive vendetta against Iraq and swung, ideologically speaking, towards an ever more overweening unilateralism.

All this goes down a treat in rightwing circles at home. When George W Bush talks of pulling troops out of the Balkans, Mr Helms's influence is at work. Some foreigners are impressed, too. Lithuania recently gave him the illustrious Medal of Grand Duke Gediminas to add to his two Senate Golden Gavels and his US police federation Golden Eagle Award. All the same, it really is time that Mr Helms, aged 79, slowed down a bit.

Luckily, an opportunity is at hand. If the Democrats can gain five seats on November 7, they will retake control of the Senate and Mr Helms will lose his chairmanship. They may also win the House of Representatives. There are many reasons for wishing the Democrats success in the congressional elections. But for vote-less foreigners, the reactionary, Blimp-ish Mr Helms is the most pressing.

A mother cried out in grief and rage as the man accused of poisoning her daughter with sulphuric acid walked free from Birmingham crown court yesterday.

The family of Karenina Longe, 27, who died on February 6 last year after drinking drain cleaner, remained composed as the jury cleared her former partner Andrew Gardner, 41, of murder after more than two days of deliberation.

But when the four women and eight men gave their second verdict "not guilty of manslaughter" an hour later, Carole Longe screamed from the public gallery: "There is no justice here. Where's the justice? It's nonsense. It's absolutely farcical."

Mr Gardner, a former laboratory technician, was accused of poisoning Dr Longe at the home they had shared in Sheldon, Birmingham because he was angry that she had ended their five-year relationship.

He initially claimed that she had drunk the acid accidentally, but later insisted to police that she had deliberately harmed herself because she was under stress.

Dr Longe drank the Liquid Plumber while visiting Mr Gardner and died the next day in Heartlands hospital, where she worked as a senior house officer. She would have suffered the "torments of hell" as acid burned through her stomach and "cooked" her organs, Stephen Linehan QC, prosecuting, had told the court.

He alleged that Mr Gardner had somehow tricked her into drinking the liquid. There was no sign that she had been forced to drink it.

Mr Gardner waited 23 minutes before calling an ambulance, telephoning plumbers for advice instead. When he finally called the emergency services Dr Longe's agonised screams could be heard in the background.

After telling paramedics that it was an accident, he sent his teenage son in the ambulance and went drinking in local pubs. He briefly visited the hospital later that day but fled to London after learning Dr Longe would die, using her cashcard to spend £800 on drink and nightclubs.

Three weeks later, after police appeals, he handed himself in, claiming to have taken an overdose of paracetamol. Doctors who examined him said it was a lie.

Mr Linehan told the court that Mr Gardner had "lied, lied and lied again" in his accounts. Even his own defence team described him as a liar and womaniser with a drink problem.

He did not give evidence during the trial, but in interviews told the police that Dr Longe had deliberately harmed herself because of stress. His claim that she had drunk three-quarters of a bottle of vodka that morning was proved false by a post-mortem examination.

Mr Gardner claimed he had not called an ambulance because he did not realise how serious the situation was and feared that a suicide attempt would damage Dr Longe's career. He said he had fled to London out of panic.

The prosecution cast doubt on key parts of his story, such as his claim that Dr Longe had first complained of stomach pains while making love.

The liquid she drank was more than 93% sulphuric acid and would have burned her instantly. Four weeks after her death it was still burning holes in her clothes.

Mr Gardner lived in Zimbabwe until 1988, working on the farm of his wealthy parents after a brief spell fighting in the civil war, but moved to England after his stormy and violent marriage broke up.

Mr Gardner met Dr Longe while both were working at St Bartholomew's hospital in London. He had a child with another woman and continued to to live with her until he followed Dr Longe to Birmingham in September 1998.

But the relationship became strained as Mr Gardner failed to find a job and drank heavily. On the Monday before her death he hit her and kneed her in the stomach during an argument. She moved into hospital lodgings and told her mother the relationship was over. Mr Gardner denied this.

Courtenay Griffiths QC, for the defence, told the jury: "I'm not asking you to like this man, this alcoholic, this clear womaniser, this fickle individual, who left his 15-year-old boy to, in fact, clear up the mess, sponging off a stressed-out young female doctor.

"You've got good reason to dislike him. You may even feel he's responsible for her death. But responsibility for her death and guilt of her murder are two completely different things."

In a statement Mr Gardner said he "remains devastated by the suicide of Miss Longe. This prosecution was not based on hard evidence but on pandering to people's emotions. We are therefore grateful to the jury for preventing a miscarriage of justice."

But family and friends refused to accept that the popular, high-achieving doctor could have committed suicide.

Her mother said: "We all know Nina Longe would not kill herself. Everybody who knew her knew she was a young woman who had everything to live for.

"She was very focused, very organised, but very compassionate. She was mature beyond her years and I think she would have gone on to realise her dream and lead a very full life."

Dr Longe, born in Lagos, was sent to a boarding school in Yorkshire at 13. Her family have set up a bursary in her memory, helping young doctors to carry out research or train in Africa.

Michael Mansfield QC, counsel for Jawad Botmeh and Samar Alami, told the appeal court a warning of a possible bombing had been handed to officers at a police station before the attack on the embassy.

A Chinese remedy used by prostate cancer patients appears to work, according to researchers at the University of California. It involves the preparation of eight herbs.

Any motorist caught doing more than 25mph over the speed limit on French roads will lose his or her licence on the spot, under a law giving police the power to penalise foreign drivers. It would be returned on leaving France.

The Hunt Saboteurs Association promises a "huge demonstration" today at the first meet of the Old Surrey, Burstow and West Kent Hunt.

David Elstein has been forced out of his job as chief executive of Channel 5, the often controversial broadcaster he helped launch in March 1997.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Elstein was asked to leave the company earlier this week amid boardroom tensions with executives from Channel 5's parent company RTL.

Staff at the channel were said to be shocked by the news which was announced internally at a meeting yesterday afternoon.

He is walking away with a pay-off of around £3m.

Mr Elstein will be replaced by Channel 5's director of programming, Dawn Airey, who has been in large part responsible for winning the broadcaster the sobriquet of "Channel Filth."

Mr Elstein has taken the brunt of press criticism over programming which some thought plumbed new depths with a game show fronted by a naked Keith Chegwin.

Ms Airey, 40, is understood to have recently been approached with job offers from rival broadcasters and sources said RTL was keen to keep her at Channel 5 by rewarding her with the top job.

A spokesman for RTL said "it had simply been time for a change", adding that the description of Mr Elstein's departure as a sacking would be a harsh interpretation.

Mr Elstein is understood to have had frosty relations with Richard Eyre, the former head of the ITV network who was installed as director of content when RTL took control of Channel 5 in June.

Nick Milligan, director of sales, has been promoted to deputy chief executive.

The planned sale of Britain's air traffic control system was cast into further doubt yesterday as rebel Labour MPs said they would continue to oppose it, spurred on by the government's defeat in the Lords on Thursday.

While the prime minister's spokesman insisted the government would overturn the defeat in the Commons, pressure mounted for the measures to be dropped to save the delayed transport bill. Crucial legislation governing the regulation of the railways may be lost if the bill is not passed before the Queen's speech on December 6.

Yesterday, Gwyneth Dunwoody, the chairwoman of the Commons transport select committee, urged the government to drop the part-privatisation plan. "They would be wise perhaps to accept this is not the time to go ahead with this plan," she told BBC Radio 4's The World at One.

"There is a great deal of doubt ... and this will hold up the transport bill, which contains absolutely essential bits of legislation about railways. I don't think any sensible business manager is so wedded to a rather pointless idea that they want to put it ahead of everything else in their programme."

The former transport minister, Gavin Strang, MP for Edinburgh East and Musselburgh, described the Lords vote as "an important and significant defeat" and said it provided the government with "an opportunity to walk away from this privatisation with dignity". He rejected ministers' claims that safety was the primary consideration.

Martin Salter, Labour MP for Reading West and a former Heathrow baggage handler, warned that rebel MPs would continue to vote against the government - as 47 did the last time it was in the Commons - or abstain. He said the rail crisis would make MPs even more resolute.

The government argues that putting 51% into private ownership would bring in £1.3bn investment in the next decade and improve efficiency. But the plans have drawn opposition from pilots and air traffic controllers as well as MPs.

The last full day of Harish Purohit's life began with the Hindu priest in a Leicester city centre night club that draws a predominantly gay clientele. At around 2.15am on October 19 he was seen by an acquaintance leaving Streetlife. He got into his silver BMW 320i and drove off. After waking, the rest of his final hours were spent between his duties at the family's temple where he was based, the care home he co-owned and his job working for social services.

Just before 11pm he went to 79 Harrison Road, a house his family was renovating, to check on its progress. In the small terraced house he died after suffering 13 stab wounds.

For the last week his family and the Hindu community have been trying to come to terms not only with his savage murder, but the fact that he was bisexual.

The police investigation is reporting little progress, but detectives believe the motive may lie in Harish's links to Leicester's gay community.

This week - the week of the largest Hindu festival, Diwali - should have been one of joy for the Purohits. Instead, at the Shree Shakti Mandir, a steady stream of mourners call into the temple founded and run by Harish's father, who brought his son up to be a priest.

Jai Purohit, 35, and Janardan Purohit, 46, are not only mourning their 42-year-old brother, but a man who had modernised the role and style of the Hindu priesthood in Britain. Those who had seen Harish conducting ceremonies did not forget him.

Five years ago I went to the Shree Shakti Mandir for the marriage of my uncle and aunt, conducted by Harish. What he did was very simple, but for the Hindu priesthood near revolutionary; he spoke in English, and explained to non-Hindus and those with a shaky grasp of their culture, each part of the wedding ceremony and its significance.

Harish told us: "Hinduism is not a religion, it's a way of life, a way of thinking, a way of disciplining oneself, physically, spiritually and emotionally.

"The word religion has been attached because there isn't any equivalent word to the Hindu Dharma in the Oxford dictionary, so the nearest thing to dharma [in English] is religion."

Most Hindu priests in this country are elderly and perform ceremonies in Hindi, catering for an audience born and raised in India, for whom the culture and rituals are part of the warp and weft of their lives.

Compassion

"People loved him for the way he delivered his services. He was more casual, more sociable," remembers Jai.

"He felt that the Hindu priesthood was not delivering enough to the younger generation, he believed there was work needed so that the younger generation would know their heritage."

Harish's brothers tell the story of how six months ago he saw a group of refugees on the street while out driving. He went home, made curry, then went to the local shop and bought its entire stock of milk and bread, grabbed a bag of clothes, and took it to the refugees.

Within the religion he was a progressive, while in wider society he fought to protect Hinduism. He lifted a bar on widows participating in rituals at wedding ceremonies and took people with learning disabilities to functions and ceremonies.

Those closest to Harish speak of his love, compassion and belief in everyone's equal rights. Nothing they knew of him suggests why he was murdered.

His body was discovered after a neighbour rang the Purohits to say there was smoke coming from the property. Jai and his father rushed to the house.

Jai said: "I saw smoke and I saw the body on the floor. When I saw the jumper I knew it was my brother, he was face down on his side. I tried to resuscitate him, but couldn't open his mouth because of rigor mortis." He had been repeatedly stabbed, the final wound inflicted close to the front door which the attackers blocked with a sofa before they set fire to the house.

Yesterday police said they wanted to question five Asian men in their thirties seen leaving an alley at the back of the house at 3.30am on October 20.

"Obviously somebody didn't like the work he did," says Janardan. "The motive is obviously jealousy of the work he was doing."

His brothers say they did not know Harish was bisexual, a fact confirmed to the Guardian by his long term partner, solicitor Anjana Joshi, and by another close friend.

Police had said Harish led a double life, but as he was known in several gay clubs and pubs across Leicester, he does not appear to have been trying hard to keep it a secret.

Harish's marriage broke down 1992 after a year. He and Ms Joshi did not marry and lived apart.

She said: "He was a truly godly person. He took away the darkness and brought in the light wherever he was."

She told the Leicester Mercury: "I knew he was bisexual and didn't have a problem with it. My love is unconditional."

Ray McClaghlan was a friend of Harish's for 17 years and they jointly ran a residential care home for people with learning disabilities. He said: "It's not fair to say he led a double life, that suggests hypocrisy. He led a life that was at one with his beliefs."

Not all in Leicester's Hindu community are comfortable with the details of Harish's private life emerging.

Jagdish Bhatt, secretary of the federation of Hindu priests of which Harish was a leading figure, said Harish was "a very good man" but criticised his homosexual conduct.

Inspirational

Rajendrabhai Chauhan, of the Gujarat Hindu Association, said: "It is something, in the Hindu community, that nobody expected. [Hinduism] is hierarchical. The priest is the highest. Everyone looks up to them. What they do does matter to the community."

Those who followed the development of Harish's Hindu philosophy and style as a priest feel his best was yet to come. Hinduism, Britain's third largest religion, is grappling with the challenge of keeping its young interested. He was one of the few leading Hindu figures making much progress.

Sumeer Kalyani, 21, president of the city's federation of Hindu youth, said Harish had a special appeal to young people: "He was an inspiration to the younger generation of Hindus. A lot of people looked up to him because he was so knowledgeable, but took the time to explain any aspect of Hinduism.

"Harish bridged that gap between old and young Hindus. Sometimes it was like a one man show in Leicester, he didn't get the support."

Kosovo will take a step closer to a final break with Yugoslavia when it holds its first democratic elections today.

The pro-independence Kosovan Albanian parties will sweep the board in the polling for municipal authorities, which will be almost totally boycotted by the few remaining Serbs.

Thousands of peacekeeeping troops will guard the 1,464 polling stations to prevent trouble. In an effort to minimise intimidation and corruption, more than 1,000 European monitors have been drafted in to support 3,000 local observers.

The Kosovo Albanians' overwhelming support for independence is a problem for the US, Britain and other Nato members, which are hoping for a reconciliation between Kosovo and the newly elected government in Belgrade. The west is afraid that any further fragmentation in the Balkans will create instability.

Hashim Thaci, the former leader of the Kosovan Liberation Army (KLA), who now heads the PDK (Democratic Party of Kosovo), said at a rally in the capital, Pristina, on Thursday: "On Saturday, it is up to you to give an answer to the dilemma of the final status of Kosovo ... your vote will put an end to the Serb dream of returning to Kosovo."

The more moderate Ibrahim Rugova, the leader of the LDK (Democratic League of Kosovo), who is likely to emerge with the biggest share of the votes, also stressed that the only solution to the Kosovan problem was a speedy move towards independence. He called for today's poll to be followed quickly by elections for an assembly and president - de facto independence.

Richard Holbrooke, the US special envoy, said such elections would be held soon, but a UN spokeswoman said it was too early to say if they would be held in the spring.

Despite the replacement of the hated Slobodan Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia by the more conciliatory Vojislav Kostunica, who called this week for the poll to be postponed, the demand for independence has increased.

Party political broadcasts have been unequivocal, showing footage of fleeing refugees and Serbian police entering Kosovo Albanian villages, a reminder of the events that led to Nato's intervention last year.

Kosovo is still recovering from that war: many buildings in Pristina are still wrecked from the Nato bombing, there are frequent power cuts, the roads are pitted and communication is irregular.

The biggest problem remains lawlessness in a country with one of the highest concentrations of guns in the world. The judicial system is biased against Serbs; crime and corruption are endemic.

The PDK, which has many members who fought in the KLA, and close links with organised crime, has control of many towns and villages. The UN is braced for bloodshed if it refuses to hand over control of any municipalities it looses."The behaviour of the PDK is the big question," a western diplomat in Pristina said.

The run-up to the election has been relatively peaceful by Kosovan standards. There was a grenade attack on Thursday, and a suspected incident of arson. Earlier in the week there was a power cut as Mr Rugova rose to deliver a speech at a rally. One of the main causes of tension is the Kosovo Albanian flag. The UN said it could not be shown at polling stations.

Almost a million Kosovo Albanians have registered to vote, and about 1,000 Serbs. In one exclusively Serb area, Zvecan, only 23 people - all Serbs - have registered to vote in 17 wards. To try to circumvent the boycott the UN administrator in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, will appoint Serbs to some municipalities.

There are no reliable opinion polls but Mr Rugova's LDK is forecast to emerge as the biggest party, Mr Thaci's PDK second and Ramush Haradinaj's AAK (Alliance for the Future of Kosovo), also pro-independence, third.

There is little difference between their programmes, most of the debate focusing on their roles in the past 10 years: Mr Thaci argues that his military option was more successful than Mr Rugova's passive resistance.

A US judge has jailed for 12 years a British grandmother who hijacked a helicopter in an attempt to free her husband, a convicted murderer, from a top security prison.

Josie Clark, 54, originally from Keighley, West Yorkshire, and latterly from the Isle of Wight, and a woman accomplice chartered the helicopter last December.

Once aboard, she drew a gun and ordered the pilot to fly to the Union correctional institution at Raiford, Florida, where her husband, Ronald, was on death row after being sentenced to death for killing a man in 1991. He had been sentenced to life for an earlier murder in 1989. Her friend, Wendy Calderon, 30, wanted to free her boyfriend.

The two women forced the helicopter pilot to turn back once they were in sight of the jail and were arrested as they tried to make their escape. Both later pleaded guilty to hijacking an aircraft.

Calderon was jailed for 11 years and three months last month and yesterday Judge Henry Lee Adams passed sentence on Clark. "This offence is unusual in any circumstance outside of a movie," he said. He also ordered Clark to pay a helicopter charter fee of £3,700.

Judge Adams said he did not give Clark the maximum 20-year sentence because she had attempted to free her husband after he was threatened by another death row prisoner, identified in court records only as Costa. She had been reluctant to cooperate with the plan and had no criminal record.

Clark met Ronald, her second husband, through a pen friends magazine; she had previously been married in England for 24 years, where she has four children. The couple married in April 1998 at the prison, where she visited him every Saturday.

She told the court she twice planned the escape then decided against it and returned to England. But he wrote to her professing his love and urging her to come back.

The Italian government and executives at BT were left red-faced this week by the collapse of the Blu consortium's bid for a third-generation mobile phone licence. Governments typically lack commercial nous; corporations, on the other hand, are often highly adept at politics. Politicians need to learn the lessons of the commercial jungle if they are ever to gain the upper hand in the state-enterprise struggle.

Dazzled by the windfalls accruing to the British and German state finances, the Italian government chose an auction process in an attempt to maximise revenues from the sale of licences for third-generation mobile operation. In a lather of excitement about the business to be gained from 3G technology, such as the market in text messaging, the telecoms groups collectively bid £22.5bn for the five UK licences. In Germany the bids totalled a third as much again.

I admit to being something of a luddite. The only text message I have received on my mobile came from BT Cellnet, offering me, as a "valued customer", a free handset upgrade. Needless to say I took them up on this no-strings offer - primarily because I could not understand how it represented good business.

Even allowing for my reactionary response to new technology, I cannot see the text-to-mobile or mobile internet revolution justifying the valuations placed on 3G licences: £22.5bn represents around £380 for every man, woman, child and baby in Britain - and that is before taking into account the cost of operating a network. It is telling that the heaviest users of text messaging are school children - they understand that a message can be sent at a fraction of the cost of a voice call.

The UK licence auction raised five times original estimates. The chancellor - already perched on a healthy public purse - has refused to be seduced by unsolicited suggestions regarding spending this windfall.

The Italians, by contrast, have a public debt mountain that must be dramatically reduced - at least if the Maastricht criteria are to be taken seriously. It has always been clear what Italy intended to do with its 3G licence fees.

What the Italians failed to allow for was the ability of the potential bidders to learn from past experience. The British auction succeeded - from the government's perspective - because 13 bidders lined up at the outset for the five licences, and because none of the participants had any experience. In the intervening months investors and analysts have questioned the wisdom behind the prices paid for licences. Balance sheets have become stretched. Telecoms share prices have tumbled, reducing the ability of successful bidders to restructure their finances. The game, in short, has changed.

Only six bidders lined up for the Italian auction of five licences. One of those, Blu, was an uneasy consortium led by motorway operator Autostrade, with our own BT as a minority shareholder but majority provider of telecoms expertise. The same BT, it should be said, whose share price has halved, the market questioning its strategy and taking fright at its projected £30bn debt burden.

Two days into the auction and it was effectively all over. The Blu consortium folded its hand, choosing instead to indulge in an unseemly round of mutual recriminations. The Italian government was left with five bidders for five licences, raising a total of only £8bn, or around half the government's publicly stated expectation. That is about £140 per head of Europe's most mobile-enthusiastic population - and only 35% of the UK take.

Whatever governments throw at them, companies invariably find ways of maximising commercial opportunities. Italy's government may rail at Blu - withholding its auction deposit in the process - but the ragbag consortium was merely the proximate cause of what has become a political crisis.

The real issue was that the telecoms groups discovered that by forming alliances to bid for licences they could shift the balance of power in the auction process away from the vendor. Hence the reduced number of runners at the start.

It is not just new industries that present governments with such problems of control and commercial exploitation. Britain's rail industry has a structure that was designed by government to maximise service to customers and returns to taxpayers. In the depth of the industry's present crisis this structure is the subject of intense scrutiny - as is its core philosophy of private ownership but public regulation.

The history of state ownership in rail, as in many other industries, is one of commercial failure. However, privatisation carries the risk that a commercial business focus undermines public service; in the case of rail, not only in safety but also in breadth of service and return to the exchequer. Government faces the dilemma of juggling service and return. Higher licence or franchise fees reduce financial returns - which must tempt commercial organisations to make economies on service quality.

There is a spectrum of industries to which these privatisation and regulation issues can be applied. At one end there is mobile telephony, in which few would blame governments for seeking to maximise revenue generation and caring little about service quality. If licence holders cannot provide the right service, market forces will resolve the problem. There will be failures, takeovers, higher charges to customers - or some combination of these three.

At the other end of the spectrum, how ever, are the "backbone" industries critical to the functioning of society in its modern form. Here, service will be of paramount importance. These industries will often also be natural monopolies, making any privatisation process particularly tricky. That is not to say competition cannot be achieved, as demonstrated by the growing number of companies offering domestic gas supplies.

It is difficult, however, to envisage a break-up of the monopoly of air traffic control - and yet here is an industry close to privatisation in the UK. I am not a nervous flyer, but it is never too late to begin being so. Frankly, in this case I am a passenger first and a taxpayer second. I do not care a jot if nobody ever makes a profit out of a safe landing.
